generation: Another week has just flown by. I drove past the new house yesterday, and noticed the front window was covered in boxes. We may receive the keys at closing, and I'm getting so excited. If everything goes smoothly this week, we'll be ready to close a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3:00 a.m. last night watching movies with Bethany; there's been a lot of movie-watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched "Thirteen," which is a film every mother of a teenager should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched "Gigli." Yes, it was just as bad as the media claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer television used to be a wasteland of reruns, but now two fantastic new shows have caught my attention, both of which I've been following religiously over the past week. One of them, "Blow Out," boasts the most flamboyant concept, yet oddly features no openly gay individuals. The show follows hairstylist Jonathan Antin as he ambitiously plans to open a second branch of his wildly successful West Hollywood salon in the upscale area of Beverly Hills. Typically, such a venture wouldn't capture my interest, yet as I was browsing through channels, I stumbled across Jonathan—exuding equal parts narcissism and blandness—as he gazed at a vacant space on Rodeo Drive and declared with grandiosity, "I am going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world right here!" And at that moment, I was hooked. Not since the days of Rocco have I found such a captivatingly foolish persona on television.

What a week it's been... I'm dealing with tendinitis in my right shoulder, just beneath the shoulder blade. Every time I use the computer mouse, it causes me significant pain, so I have to limit my arm movements. I recently went on a spree updating my website and working on other online projects, which has left my arm extremely painful. Now, it's difficult to even summon enough energy to draw. The lack of sleep only adds to my discomfort. Although I'm not feeling very positive at the moment, I'm hopeful for recovery. On a brighter note, my mom's surgery went well. Her eyesight has improved somewhat—she can now see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Despite this progress, she remains largely legally blind. We're optimistic that her vision will fully return soon.

The Kindness of Strangers

Today, I tackled laundry with the kids in tow and quickly discovered how even the simplest tasks can turn into a major ordeal. However, I also experienced the unexpected kindness of strangers—people who were genuinely sweet without any ulterior motives. Trust me, they weren't trying to win me over, considering I was covered in kid drool and decked out in my not-so-glamorous 'wash-day' attire. Plus, given my current state, there was definitely no olfactory appeal involved!

Right now, I'm multitasking by composing a post while watching a collection of No Doubt music videos, all from the comfort of my desk in my room.

It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I am in my bedroom, fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. While I don't mind doing it, I sometimes wonder why I so frequently find myself repairing someone else's computer as a favor. I'm happy to be able to show care and support to people in this way, but at what point does it become taking advantage? Over the past few weeks, I've been staying up late reading and doing other activities, so I was really looking forward to going to bed early—until I realized it made more sense to get this computer out of my room and back to its owner. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So tonight, I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again.

Could you remind me about what I wrote earlier? This is the next installment in the ongoing 'Is this a date?' saga. Following that awkward lunch, shaken confidence and all, I realized I had left out a crucial detail. Just before Pat arrived, Dustin began talking about what a great guy Pat was and how he was trying to help Pat find a girlfriend. I urge everyone to reflect before taking action. In fact, I wish every person worldwide would contemplate their actions even before getting out of bed each morning. I hope they commit to thoughtful consideration throughout the day. If they're not ready to do so, I wholeheartedly wish they'd just crawl back into bed and go back to sleep indefinitely. I'm utterly fed up with foolishness. While I'm not claiming to be the smartest person in the world, I believe it's fair to criticize those severely lacking in common sense, as I'm not discussing complex matters here. Let's see if I can focus this particular rant on a few specific types of foolishness today and save the rest for another time. Sound good? Great.

There are two major issues with the scenario I described in my previous post. First, while it's true that Bush is stimulating the economy, he's doing so ineffectively. Robert Rubin mentioned on NPR's Marketplace today that Bush could have provided the same economic boost without incurring long-term debt by implementing alternative tax cuts—specifically, temporary tax cuts aimed at benefiting low and middle-income individuals. Ah, Robert Rubin. Just hearing his name is music to our ears. Now, quickly: can you name a Bush administration cabinet member on the domestic front who matches Rubin's level of influence and expertise? Still thinking? Keep pondering... Have you ever found yourself deep in thought, reflecting on life? Picture this: you’re sitting in math class, bored out of your mind, and you start to ponder what processes in your brain allow you to grasp mathematical concepts. Suddenly, it hits you—you exist, you’re sitting in a math class, and you begin to question why. In that moment, you appreciate the sheer wonder of existence. Then, it dawns on you just how absurd and random this train of thought is, and it feels quite silly. Ever been there? I really dislike when that happens. You know what else gets on my nerves? Block schedules. Who thought that was a good idea? It’s clear to anyone that forcing students to endure two and a half hours in any subject is nothing short of cruel and unusual punishment.

I've decided that Monopoly has finally run its course in my life, and I vow never to touch that infernal iron piece (the game token, not the heated appliance) again. Tonight, Andy narrowly defeated me by a few dollars and claimed victory in the game, or perhaps I allowed him to win because he's leaving in a few hours and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However, regardless of the narrative, it pales in comparison to this Texas-sized headache I’m currently enduring. Thankfully, I've taken some Aleve, and it’s working wonders. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation—as for the phone, it was the one that helped me imagine wrapping the cord around your neck... At the drive-in.

Today has felt like a marathon. We just returned from Indiana, and I find myself needing to be selective about what I write. There’s so much to say, but I’m running low on time and energy. To start, I must express that camp was incredible, surpassing all my expectations. God has been doing amazing things in my life recently, and it’s been truly remarkable. I also have a dentist appointment at 9 AM, which isn't my favorite, but I'd prefer to tackle it now rather than during my first month of the surgery rotation. I can't stand being just another piece in the game (as I told Cassie, "I'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard that insists on moving like a knight"), and I'm uneasy about not knowing what to expect.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current governor of Uttar Pradesh, as early as 1996, had cautioned about the looming threat of a potential 'third Islamic state' emerging in the subcontinent. TV Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present governor, had forecasted this serious threat in a series of articles published in The Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie poses an important question: now that it is known that Rajeswar, not himself or Mr. Advani, authored these warnings, does this lend credibility to the concerns? Or should one conclude that because Rajeswar wrote about this issue, he is a hidden communalist and should not remain governor of Uttar Pradesh?

Last night was a disaster. I had to get rid of the sweater I was knitting, despite having completed about 14 inches. I ended up wasting around $10 worth of yarn, considering it costs $8 per skein. Unfortunately, by the time I reached the armholes, there were too many stitches, and the mohair kept tangling as I knitted, making it difficult to unravel the rows. The yarn frequently snapped. Last night in class, we were discussing the assigned reading for the week, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement," while the second focuses on "displacement." In the initial chapter, Casey highlights the difference that in our modern world and culture, time is viewed as the central organizing principle: we are constantly running out of time, saving time, or just in time. He argues that centering culture around place can create a more grounded community. (This is a brief overview, just in case my professor or any classmate reads this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly captured my attention.

This weekend was quite enjoyable. After a long hiatus, I indulged in some of nature's greenery, listened to a lot of Nevermore, which I realize I should have embraced much sooner, and immersed myself in reading. I managed to finish three books: Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," Larry Niven's "World of Ptavvs," and Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." "Heavy Weather" offered a captivating cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA ravaged by global warming and widespread anarchy. Although the story was clever, well-paced, and generally convincing, I must admit that it didn't leave me with any particularly profound impressions of the plot or characters. Both were skillfully crafted and vividly portrayed, yet it was a good book rather than a truly great one, in my opinion.

Fall 1974: I felt like I was tackling my high school algebra book for the 13th attempt, trying to push through the second chapter. I wasn't a math enthusiast back then, and I still am not. I dislike math; in fact, I'm math phobic. You get the idea. As I struggled to grasp algebra, the doorbell rang. Setting my book aside, I went to answer the door, but no one was there. Wonderful. I went back to my studies and had just started to catch a faint glimmer of understanding emerging from my subconscious when the doorbell rang again. Just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Exactly what a struggling math student needs—an unwelcome practical joker.

I'm finding this uncomfortable. Investigative reporting feels quite unsettling to me. To clarify, the article I'm working on and its potential consequences are not something I can find ease with. Perhaps it's because I lack a strong belief in it; I can't entirely grasp its essence. The tension behind it, the intense passion required to challenge it—that isn't something I'm familiar with. Yesterday, my colleagues from the bank and I embarked on an adventure to Guintubdan, La Carolota. For most of us, it was a brand new experience. We hiked towards the waterfalls, a journey that took approximately 30 minutes. It left us all a bit breathless, but we persevered and reached our destination. The water was incredibly cold, like ice, numbing our bodies as we dipped in. We spent less than an hour there before heading to another set of nearby falls, requiring another 30-minute trek. The effort was undoubtedly worthwhile, as the falls exuded a tranquil beauty, and the entire scene was breathtaking. It felt as though one could truly connect with nature, becoming part of its serene rhythm. Immersing myself in the frigid water was akin to communing with Mother Earth, while the crisp air and chilled water could easily lull you into a peaceful slumber.

Some individuals are eager to make connections, highlighting that the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. Observers will be drawn from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This marks the first occasion such a team will attend a U.S. presidential election. Meanwhile, a group of thirteen congressional Democrats, including four from New York, have requested U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to Florida for this year’s presidential voting. Respectfully, I disagree with this stance. Based on the available information, it appears that the OSCE is here to learn from the U.S. election process, rather than to oversee it, contrary to the initial partisan and immature appeal for U.N. involvement.

The GOP faces criticism over recruitment practices, leading to the relocation of naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville after complaints emerged about GOP activists registering new citizens as Republicans. The article, written by Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, describes a typical citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville with around 200 people becoming new Americans. Before departing the June 29 event, an immigration official encouraged the new citizens to visit a voter registration table—a common practice at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: Republican volunteers were distributing forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked to enroll all the new voters as GOP members. Linda Cross, attending to witness her husband Dario Cruz take his citizenship oath, found the situation suspicious.

I appreciated the concept of framing that as an offense—perhaps it could have been an alternative to being accused of witchcraft. As a blogger from outside the United States, I’ve been somewhat hesitant to wade into these discussions, especially those concerning flags. However, since I brought up the topic (though not the act of flag-burning), I feel compelled to share my thoughts. Firstly, I believe that enacting a law against flag-burning is utterly irrational. Once you start granting a symbol—any symbol—such automatic reverence and protection, you're making a small yet significant move towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently unstable; they do not inherently represent anything. It is how they are perceived or what they are made to represent that holds significance.

Hello, so I watched "Troy" with my family tonight, and I must say, I wasn't impressed. I'm too tired to delve deeply into specifics, but I felt it had potential. However, too much effort seemed to be focused on the magnificent set design, rather than on establishing a strong tone and theme. While it presented the story, it wasn't particularly captivating, and I didn't feel like I gained anything from watching it. The character development was quite weak. Furthermore, I found the score to be poor, almost as if it were trying to mimic "Gladiator." In "Gladiator," the use of a background score with a moaning woman was effective because it supported and enhanced a genuinely compelling narrative.

Let's give a warm welcome to the latest addition to the atom/RDF/RSS reader family: PulpFiction 1.0 by Freshly Squeezed Software. This new application offers plenty of native app features. It’s worth noting that it isn’t available for free or as open-source software, which is a frequently discussed topic online. Users can test it for 15 days before deciding to either stop using it or purchase it for $25. A standout feature is the ability to manage each post as a distinct item—you can move, store, label, or even delete them as you wish. This functionality is particularly appealing for those who track news closely. Additionally, the software imports and exports OPML files, which is to be expected.

Have you ever experienced a day where nothing seems to make sense? No? In that case, you might want to stop reading, as the following won't resonate with you. It's either scoring goals or missing out, and this game is absolutely fantastic. I have nothing negative to say about it because it has exceeded my expectations and will probably surpass yours too. The gameplay features fluid movements without bugs or crashes, and there's a wealth of story and content to dive into. Each day offers multiple options like various practices, events (including sponsorships), and games. This review is based solely on my experience with MyCareer mode, which has been a flawless 10/10. The face scan feature worked excellently for me (although the first attempt resulted in an odd-looking forehead). Remember, by using the MyNBA2K17 app, you can scan your face for free and earn daily VC. #sellout

Attention Magic enthusiasts: Wizards of the Coast appears hesitant to develop a compelling digital version of the game. At its heart, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience meant to be enjoyed with friends (or friendly rivals), filled with laughter, good-natured banter, and impressive game-winning moves. Unfortunately, Wizards seems to have lost sight of this. Players who opt to compete with friends won't earn gold, and gold plays a crucial role. It’s so essential that they've instituted a daily cap—reasonable, given that gold unlocks everything in the game. However, prepare yourself for a tedious 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, to whom you can't even communicate. Should you decide to play for free, anticipate dedicating about four hours per day for up to a month, on your own, just to unlock the cards.

As the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negatives first. Personally, I'm not a fan of prequels, as they seem to move the story backward rather than forward—a common issue with all prequels. However, they do provide additional narrative depth. Unfortunately, the combat feels lackluster and doesn't possess the refinement that Arkham City achieved. As of this recommendation (October 26, 2013), there's a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from being completed (though it doesn't affect the main storyline). Some gadgets are assigned inconvenient hotkeys, requiring you to stretch across the keyboard, which might seem minor, but during combat, it could disrupt your combo.

In the 2013 release of Shadow Warrior, they've significantly improved the game. The boss battles are exhilarating, and the weapons deliver a satisfying experience—perhaps not quite on par with those in DOOM 2016, but still impressive. The enemies are balanced well, not overly tough, provided you manage elemental aspects and upgrades wisely. The upgrade system is well-adjusted, becoming intuitive once you familiarize yourself with it. The use of elemental features and limited ammunition subtly encourages you to switch between different weapons. There are numerous cool, unique weapons—in stark contrast to the random generation often seen in Borderlands—that remain effective throughout most of the game. The soundtrack is fantastic, especially the main theme, with notable contributions from Stan Bush.

There are so many things that went wrong. I don't even know where to begin this review. This all pertains to my career. My player is an outside scorer, point guard, standing at 1.71m, with maxed stats and all the necessary perks. Now, can someone explain why shooting ability is linked to a player's height? Why can't a person who is 1.74m be as proficient in shooting as someone who is 1.71m? In real life, I am 1.87m, and when I created my first player with this height, I discovered that I couldn't exceed a skill level of 89. Why is that? It feels like pure discrimination! Moreover, why doesn't the game inform me of these limitations before I create a character or even when I hit the skill cap after weeks of playing?!

Although I can't personally recommend this game, it's not entirely bad. The gunplay is satisfactory if you can afford to buy gun parts, which leads to my main issue with this game: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook this aspect, the game would be enjoyable because the hardsuit is a blast to use and the HRV is a brilliant concept. I'd prefer this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction structure is quite off-putting to me. If you're okay with this setup, by all means, enjoy the game. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, it's best to pass on this one; it's not our style.

Although not without its flaws, this game has been incredibly enjoyable. The save system and potential for sudden death can be a bit frustrating. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around the 10-hour mark of a roughly 20-hour game. I wish there had been a save point to reload at that moment. To prevent such catastrophic setbacks, I've since resorted to using a third-party mod/save tool. Additionally, the aiming reticle feels somewhat small, and the zoom is underpowered. Despite these issues, it’s been an absolute blast. Normally, I'm not a fan of zombie games, but the blend of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat 'em up elements is fantastic. I've been playing as much as I can, always telling myself, "just one more mission," or "just one more supply run," or running off to find a safe spot before turning the game off.

This is an outstanding strategy game! Having played every other wargame, like European Escalation and ALB, I can confidently say this one is a perfect fit. The variety of units is impressive, and while I can't specify the total number, there are countless options! The graphics are stunning, the sound design is excellent, and the overall gameplay is truly epic. Even the in-game chat box at the main menu provides great entertainment, and I am not exaggerating. However, if you think this game is 'easy' or you're new to the strategy genre, be prepared to invest some time to master it. Don't be discouraged if you lose a lot of units at first. Just remember to plan ahead and always include anti-air and anti-tank measures in your strategy.

Initially, I had a negative bias against this game before actually playing it. I wasn't even sure if I should buy it since the concept of the portal gun and portals felt strange to me, even as a fan of science fiction. However, I quickly realized how wrong I was. The jokes and voice acting in this game are outstanding—simply amazing. It's not overly cheesy (okay, sometimes it is a bit cheesy), and each character in the story brings their own unique sense of humor. The diverse personalities of these characters are truly distinct. Additionally, the level design is exceptional. By the way, I've never played the first Portal game, but one of these days, I plan to if I can find the time. I probably wouldn't have played this one if I hadn't experienced the sequel first.

Let's dive into the pros and cons of this game before I share my final thoughts. 

Pros:
+ Features some of the best characters 
+ Engaging story 
+ Abundance of content 
+ Customizable character (choose to be male or female)
+ Ability to form relationships with most companions (yes, fangirls, there's a love interest!)

Cons:
- Poor graphics (though I believe graphics are not crucial)
- Awkward love scenes 
- Presence of invisible walls 
- One mission felt dull, but personal preferences vary
+/- This is neutral, but note that your created protagonist doesn't have voice lines

Now, onto my thoughts. I absolutely love this game. It's probably one of the best role-playing games, or even games in general, that I've ever played. If you're an RPG fan, you probably already own this gem.

For those in their thirties, particularly in the UK, this is a nostalgic journey back to the days of watching the ever-annoying Timmy Mallett just for that brief, five-minute Transformers cartoon segment. The original voice actors for characters like Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and others have returned, and they are immediately recognizable. The iconic cartoon transformation sound remains intact. Graphically, the cel-shaded style is flawlessly executed, capturing the essence of Generation One perfectly. Beyond that, it's genuinely an enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well designed. Transforming during battles is often essential and is seamlessly integrated into combos, distinguishing it from High Moon's excellent War for and Fall of Cybertron games. Another notable difference is the strong emphasis on melee combat, although some enemies, like Seekers, necessitate a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a short time, but it didn’t stand out. I spent more time attempting to log in than actually playing. There's a bug that claims the terms of service have been updated, but when you click 'accept,' the message just reappears. You have to restart the client to resolve this issue. That alone isn't too bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts? They claim it's necessary for DLC, yet this seems unnecessary. Moreover, it's irreversible, so now a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is just average. It clearly imitates Call of Duty, but they've somehow managed to make the gunplay even worse. How is that even possible?

Running smoothly at 4k resolution and 60fps on a GTX 970, this game offers dual audio options and comes with Neptune gear—what's not to love? It's an excellent port and a fantastic entry point for newcomers to the series. Just be aware that there is a lot of dialogue, most of which you can skip. As usual, I recommend using a gamepad, but I personally had no issues using a keyboard and mouse setup, with both options being fully customizable. The pricing seems fair, and I would have been satisfied with the purchase. More than half of the DLC is included for free, providing plenty of content to explore. I would recommend this game to all fans of JRPGs, anime, and visual novels, as long as you don't mind lengthy pauses between the action. Cheers. For a no-commentary playlist, check out: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I encountered no performance issues even at the initial release, and with all the subsequent patches, it now plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, this is an outstanding and entertaining game, although the format might be slightly frustrating—every time you advance the story, the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies. I especially enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play as Batman alongside another character. The option to use a controller for most parts of the game, while switching to a mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments, was greatly appreciated. Navigating your Batmobile around the free-roam city, particularly during chases with the APC commanders, becomes quite enjoyable once you master using the brakes for skidding around corners. Once you get the hang of it, driving around the city is genuinely a delight!

This is an exceptional first-person shooter, no doubt about it. The visuals, audio, and gameplay are outstanding, with excellent FPS mechanics, an engaging storyline, memorable characters, impeccable voice work, and a fantastic soundtrack. However, it's not for the easily disturbed—some cutscenes are quite intense and graphic. That being said, when a game is this impressive overall, its shortcomings become more noticeable. Here's what stood out to me: - There's no SLI support, which is frustrating. I had to pause playing until I could upgrade my GPU because it performed poorly on my old dual GPU GTX 590. Make sure you have a decent single GPU card. - Ridiculously small obstacles are often impossible to climb over.

English is not my first language, as I am Dutch, so please pardon any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this amazing game. I will organize my review into several categories: 

1. **Graphics:** The game features a comic-like style, with very sleek graphics and no unnecessary details. The color schemes are well-chosen and complement the game perfectly. The graphics settings can be adjusted to 'high' without overloading your system. I play this game on an i5 Pentium processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card, 8GB of memory, and it operates smoothly on Windows 8.1.

2. **Controls:** This game is versatile, allowing you to play with either a keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller.

I've invested countless hours into this game, which is a testament to how much I enjoy it. This is precisely what I hoped a search game inspired by COD would be like. However, don't purchase this game expecting it to resemble COD, Battlefield, or any other typical shooter. It's in a league of its own and ought to be appreciated as such. I've lost count of how many times I hear new players complain about getting killed quickly. Heaven forbid you get shot in the face and die instantly—such things do happen in reality. Edit: After playing this game for some time and spending quite a bit on it, I can confidently say it's among the best multiplayer games out there. It's a great alternative for when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

After spending just two hours with this game, I find myself overwhelmed with laughter. The humor is fantastic! The gameplay is robust, the art design stunning, and the music not only high quality but perfectly fitting to the experience. The story and world-building have captured my interest, and the puzzles offer genuine enjoyment. However, the standout feature of this game is undeniably its comedy. Anyone familiar with RPGs, from their inception to now, will appreciate the clever jokes, parodies, and references. Even newcomers to RPGs will find themselves entertained by its wit. For those who have experienced Final Fantasy 7 or X, this game is a must-play. Without spoiling too much, I must say I had to pause after two hours to rest my cheeks from constant laughter and smiling. What a delightful experience it has been so far!

I sincerely apologize, as I generally aim to support free-to-play games and indie developers, but unfortunately, I didn't enjoy this game. The description seemed perfectly suited to my interests, yet the execution left me unimpressed. Despite my love for puzzle and exploration games, I found this one entirely unintuitive. Even after searching for guidance on how to progress, I simply didn't find the gameplay enjoyable. Additionally, the game seems to lack a pause button, or if it does have one, it's completely elusive to me. Given that many sequences in the game are timed, this feels like a significant oversight. Furthermore, it seems more like a collection of cutscenes than an actual game, leaving me often twiddling my thumbs.

This game... Wow, where do I begin? It was utterly breathtaking, from the story to the graphics—I was completely captivated. The narrative wasn't just any story; it made me feel as though I was that character, eagerly unraveling each new chapter. The gameplay was fantastic, and it surprisingly taught me a lot about myself, particularly my newfound fear of heights, which I discovered in the ice caverns. My stomach was in knots the entire time, but I persevered for Uncle Fred! If you guys released a DLC or a sequel, I'd be the first in line to purchase it and recommend it to everyone I know. A heartfelt thank you to everyone involved in creating this; you've crafted an absolutely stunning game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where you develop your civilization towards achieving specific goals or 'victories.' Unlike its predecessors, which were set on Earth's historical timeline, covering eras like the Stone Age, Medieval, and Modern Age, this installment projects you into the future with the mission of colonizing a new planet. What I appreciate about this game is that 2K Games ventured into new territory with innovative mechanics, such as the affinity system and the orbital layer. However, I found that these additions could sometimes make the game overwhelming. One area for improvement could be the incorporation of fresh artwork, particularly in the environments encountered during interactions with other leaders.

02/07/2014 - Unfortunately, I cannot wholeheartedly recommend or fully enjoy this game. In the brief time I've played it, I've realized that I'd be hooked if not for these two critical issues. First, the absence of Australian servers results in a red bar that significantly hampers gameplay and introduces unbearable lag. Even in offline training mode, I experienced stuttering and lag, which is baffling. Combined with the poor ping, it completely detracts from the gaming experience. Secondly, there are rampant graphical artifacts affecting everything from menus and backgrounds to training and in-game content. This issue is unprecedented with my current graphics card, and although I suspected it might be due to my overclocking, resetting the GPU to stock settings had no effect.

Late last night, I completed this. While the story itself isn't particularly deep or captivating, the storytelling is what truly sets this game apart. The atmosphere is thoroughly immersive, and the numerous collectibles greatly enhance the narrative. I gained a lot of insight into the world of Batman, so it was somewhat disappointing that the game featured so few bosses. However, there are plenty of opportunities in future games to address this. The combat strikes a good balance in terms of difficulty, though it leans towards being easy. Leveling up Batman wasn't particularly rewarding; it's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that introduce exciting new gameplay mechanics. Unlocking previously inaccessible areas delivers a satisfying sense of progress.

To the Moon" is far more than just a game—it's an extraordinary journey, and one of the most remarkable experiences I've ever had. Did you find Telltale's "The Walking Dead" moving? Well, prepare yourself, because it doesn't compare to "To the Moon!" Never before have I felt so beautifully melancholic and fulfilled by a fictional narrative. This masterpiece, in my view, represents the apex of storytelling, paired with a soundtrack that is both exquisitely charming and perfectly complementary. Yes, the controls can be a bit tricky, and the gameplay may not be its strongest aspect, but the narrative is so compelling that it didn't bother me in the slightest. Moreover, the humor in the game is exceptional and seamlessly blends with the story's dignified essence. And let's not forget—the Doctor Who references are abundant!

Bastion is an exceptionally brilliant game, featuring a captivating storyline. Set in the aftermath of a great calamity, you are tasked with rebuilding the bastion. The game offers a wide array of choices, including decisions on which structures to construct for an advantage, which weapons to wield, and the power-ups to apply to those weapons, as well as selecting drinks that grant you bonus effects. The game's art style and music are outstanding, with vibrant visuals that challenge the notion that the apocalypse must be dreary. Most notably, the game includes narration that responds to your actions as the player. For instance, if you select a weapon and later switch it for another in the armory, the narration reflects your choice, acknowledging the new weapon you carry.

I initially purchased this game during its early development phase, back when the only currency available was spacebux and there was no "tech tree." This was when the game truly shone. At that time, all guns were equally overpowered, eliminating any issues with imbalance—everyone had the chance to defeat anyone else at any moment. Furthermore, the game used to provide unlimited gun slots and offered five loadouts. You would expect that a game boasting "bajillions of guns" would offer more than just 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before requiring additional purchases. At one point, I had amassed about three pages of guns and was brimming with new ideas for more, as I personally found that aspect the most enjoyable.

This game turned out to be a delightful surprise. It's not uncommon for products to receive glowing reviews that fail to live up to expectations, but in this instance, the accolades truly capture the enjoyment of this clever little game. Combining elements of a classic 2D platformer with a MOBA, it pulls off the blend with finesse. Surprisingly, I found myself liking characters I typically wouldn't favor in other MOBA games. While I anticipated sticking to my usual preferences, I decided to try a melee tank and was thrilled with the results, leading me to explore more characters as they became available through gameplay. The art style and interface possess a quirky charm, and as a result, I've adopted one of the characters as my avatar and use a wallpaper I created from a card set for the game.

I've just begun playing, and I'm absolutely enamored with this game. With my headphones on, I immerse myself for hours. It's been quite some time since a game had such a captivating effect on me. The music perfectly sets the mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate each combat encounter, and the developers have optimized the combat mechanics brilliantly. Initially, I had reservations about the naval combat system, but it's incredibly satisfying to decimate multiple fleets at once! The only way to be defeated in this game is by failing to retreat. If the battle seems overwhelming, it's best to retreat, regroup, and launch a counterattack. Kudos to the developers for delivering an amazing experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced numerous changes, particularly affecting the series' protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original saga might feel disappointed with the transformation of their cherished character, these changes are undoubtedly beneficial, as demonstrated by the new game developed by Ninja Theory. "DMC" serves as an ideal entry point for newcomers to the series, exploring the origins of a once arrogant and cynical Dante, and illustrating his evolution from cynicism to selflessness. The game presents a well-defined narrative arc for this revamped Dante, transforming him into a captivating character. The storyline follows Dante as he enters the corrupt world he had previously chosen to ignore.

Where do I begin with this incredibly beautiful game? Its story is utterly enchanting, filled with meticulous detail, and it's a delightful mix of joy, cheesy jokes, mischievous dogs, and hidden surprises. It strikes a perfect balance, being serious when necessary but never shying away from moments of humor. The character design is impeccable, showcasing a variety of personalities and secrets. What sets it apart from other RPGs is its unique approach—you don't have to kill anyone, a rare concept in the genre. Drawing significant inspiration from Earthbound, one of the finest RPGs I've encountered, it's clear that this game promises greatness. The soundtrack is also outstanding; it's the best I've heard in a long time.

I'm recommending this primarily because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. Personally, the game left no impact on me. Half of its storyline depends heavily on shock value, which neither surprised nor emotionally affected me. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it wasn't complex enough to provoke a reaction. The other half aims to depict (quite literally) a person's mental decline, addressing themes of obsession, hallucination, depression, and more. In concept, it's an intriguing idea. However, it only took me 10 minutes to finish, even as I carefully absorbed every detail.

Do I really need to explain why Portal is incredible? Portal is a puzzle game that presents you with a concept and then lets you dive right in. It's a fantastic way to challenge your mind while still being enjoyable. Although it's not heavy on story, Portal paved the way for one of the most acclaimed games of 2011. I still find myself playing it and conquering it when I'm feeling bored, relishing the opportunity to revisit what laid the foundation for a legend and has since become a legend itself. 

Gameplay-wise, Portal is straightforward, at least in terms of explanation. You manipulate portals to your advantage and use buttons to activate different parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: one you can press and one that requires a cube to be placed on it.

If you can look past the bugs (I personally encountered only two: one minor and the other rather annoying), I highly recommend this game for those interested in space exploration. Note: both issues have been resolved, and one fix even increased my FPS from 60–90 to 80–120. Since many reviews focus on specs, here are mine: an i5 6600K (~€200), Radeon RX480 (~€200), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~€150), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (~€70), totaling around €650, which is definitely in the medium price range. Admittedly, this setup is relatively new and consistently runs at 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled. I find it hard to believe 90% of the comments claiming to have high-end setups only achieving 20 FPS.

Do you remember Age of Mythology? It's been quite some time since we've seen an RTS game of that caliber. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes remarkably close to matching that level of excellence in my personal list of favorite RTS games. Adding a grand strategy mode reminiscent of Risk, it truly hits the mark. I strive to remain objective, despite the sheer fun of transforming into a dragon to support your troops by attacking, commanding unit production, and directing forces all at once. I truly appreciate complex RTS games such as Civilization V. However, these modern titles tend to overwhelm players by cramming intricate mechanics, charts, and resources into a single, convoluted game mode.

Undertale is a masterpiece that transcends the sum of its parts. The graphics are commendable for a retro game, and the music is delightful. However, when combined, they create truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script masterfully ranges from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes blending all of these elements simultaneously while cleverly subverting typical RPG tropes. And this is without even delving into the game's rich world, memorable characters, engrossing story, and engaging gameplay—I could easily dedicate pages to each of these aspects. Instead, I'll simply say this: if you appreciate RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours at any point in your life, make sure to play this game.

I've only had this game for a few months, yet within that brief period, two DLCs have been released, alongside patches that have elevated an already fantastic game to excellence. The developers actively engage with the community, which is evident in the discussion forums and developer diaries. Although there is a relatively steep learning curve to mastering the game's mechanics—which I'm still navigating—this depth of strategy offers numerous ways to achieve goals and capitalize on various situations. In my opinion, the game is almost endlessly replayable. I find myself fully immersed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is an engaging game for the initial hours of play. However, beyond that, you may start to notice its repetitive nature in combat, enemies, and overall gameplay. A notable strength is the dedication of its developers, who frequently release updates packed with substantial new content, from extensive system changes to new warframes and other enhancements. It's an enjoyable game for casual play, although it might struggle to keep your interest for more than a few months unless you particularly enjoy grinding. The advantage is that it's free to play, so I recommend giving it a try. If you're in need of a quick gaming experience, it's worth checking out.

This game is incredibly boring. I purchased it thinking it was the PC version of the well-loved PS2 game, "Katamari Damacy." Unfortunately, it falls far short of that expectation. In this game, you progress by absorbing larger objects to increase your size and take on even bigger ones. However, the gameplay lacks smoothness, the levels are unimaginative, and the overall experience feels like a surreal horror show. Rather than being entertaining, it leaves you feeling gloomy and questioning the value of existence. Every 'living' creature in the game, from small pets to humans, makes me suspect the developers might have a peculiar interest in taxidermy.

"Allow me to clarify a few points. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was eager to try out this game when I first learned about it. My initial reaction was, 'Wow, a simulator about the journey to becoming president? That sounds exciting!' Unfortunately, it didn’t quite live up to my expectations. The game begins by asking you to choose between being a Republican or a Democrat, with no option for independents or third parties. Although slightly disheartened, I remained hopeful and continued to explore the game’s possibilities. To its credit, the character customization feature, though somewhat limited, is quite entertaining. It’s the only campaign where you can literally decide whether or not to include a head in your appearance.

Here are my stats at the time of writing this review: - 8.6 hours spent completing the game - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - No achievements earned out of 15 What I liked: - The visuals were impressive up until the final level, the ice caves - While the story wasn't particularly strong, the ending (after the closing credits) was satisfying enough to justify the time spent playing What I disliked: - The visual appeal of the last level was lacking - The gameplay in the last level became significantly more difficult, leading to a frustrating cycle of repeated attempts to succeed - The achievements are overly challenging, with 13 out of 15 being unlocked by less than 2.1% of players!

Pros: + Excellent graphics.  
Cons: - Numerous bugs, particularly environmental ones where you might get stuck or your shots could hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy. - The game tends to hold your hand excessively. - Unintelligent AI. - Enemies seem uncannily aware of your location once you've been spotted. - The enemy's accuracy is incredibly precise, reminiscent of the frustrating first Ghost Warrior. - Poorly designed checkpoints and save systems. - A dull storyline that fails to capture interest. I would not recommend this game unless it's offered at a 90% discount. Even then, I find it an excessively tedious experience, playing only to finish it and move on to the next game in my library. Reflecting on the time I spent on the first Ghost Warrior, which was equally dull and left me feeling relieved once completed, I doubt I'll see this through to the end.

Review for November 29, 2015: I strongly advise against purchasing this game because the servers are offline, making it unplayable. No compres este juego, servidores no funcionan. No puedes jugar. When I was able to play, I found it enjoyable. It reminds me of the Steve Miller Band song, "Take the Money and Run." It's a frustrating experience: go on, take the money and run! (Link: https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54) --- English: Spent 73 minutes with the game and, wow, just an hour in! It's fantastic! However, some guns are overpowered, and matchmaking can be unfair. But, truth be told, Battlefield 3 had its matchmaking faults too, pairing newbies with high-level players who seemed invincible, as shooting them in the face had no effect!

I can understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't quite right for me. I own a Vive and prefer engaging with room-scale games using the controllers. While the vastness of the game's universe is initially breathtaking, I found that this same scale limited my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and the time required to reach interesting experiences at the start were too overwhelming for my preferences. If I had more patience and more time to dedicate to gaming, I might find this game compelling. However, since I lack both, there are many other VR games that I'd prefer to spend my time on.

This is, without a doubt, my all-time favorite first-person shooter. It's not for those who prefer a run-and-gun Rambo style. The recoil and ballistics are depicted with realism, as even a single hit to the chest, neck, or head with a rifle-caliber bullet is almost always lethal, unless it's just a graze. Bullets drop over distances, necessitating short, controlled bursts to stay on target. There's no limitless ammunition; if you frequently reload halfway through your magazine, you'll end up with a pouch filled with partially full magazines. You can't sprint indefinitely; prolonged running will affect your aim as you struggle to catch your breath. To stabilize your aim, rest your weapon on your elbows when prone or on a window sill. Standing results in compromised accuracy.

Let me begin by saying that I didn’t purchase the original version of the game when it first launched. I actually bought it during a sale, which included the expansion, so I missed the initial issues some people reported. I thoroughly enjoyed the game; it was challenging in the early stages but incredibly rewarding when you mastered it. Regarding XCOM 2, I absolutely love it. The game runs smoothly for me on medium settings, and I'm using a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game automatically set itself to high, which caused it to run a bit sluggishly, but it was far from unplayable. Once I adjusted it to medium, everything ran smoothly. I'm uncertain whether I'm simply fortunate with how games perform on my setup, but it seems like most negative reviews come from individuals who seem rather demanding.

+RPG leveling system +Wide variety of ship types +Physics-based movement for ships and projectiles/missiles +User-friendly resource management +Dark humor

World leaders convene amidst growing uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political figures from across the globe arrive at the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will deliberate on topics ranging from China's economic influence to Iraq's prospects following Sunday's elections. Prominent attendees include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, among more than 20 leaders and heads of state. In contrast to previous years, protests against the WEF are anticipated to be subdued. Anti-globalization activists have canceled a demonstration planned for the weekend. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the alternative World Social Forum, scheduled to coincide with Davos's more lavish event.

Fiat and General Motors (GM) face a looming deadline of midnight on February 1st to resolve their dispute regarding a potential takeover. This deadline will trigger Fiat's option to sell its automotive division to GM, a clause from their 2000 alliance agreement. However, GM is currently uninterested in acquiring Fiat's unprofitable unit, particularly given its own financial struggles in Europe. On Tuesday, news of stalled negotiations caused Fiat's shares to drop by 1.2%, a stark contrast to Monday's 4% increase fueled by takeover speculation. GM is reportedly proposing around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to withdraw from the partnership, asserting that Fiat's previous actions—selling its finance branch and diluting GM's stake through a capital increase—invalidated the original agreement. The 2000 alliance resulted from competitive moves by both GM and DaimlerChrysler to form a partnership with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticized the immense financial burden of the Iraq War, arguing that the billions of pounds expended on the conflicts in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better used to alleviate poverty. Speaking as the leader of the Catholic Church in England and Wales on BBC Radio 4, he shared these views and plans to reiterate them during his Christmas Midnight Mass. In his Christmas message, the Cardinal condemned the war in Iraq as a "terrible" misuse of funds. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have been vocal in their opposition to the conflict. During BBC Radio 4's "Thought for the Day" segment, he lamented the fact that vast sums have been diverted to war efforts rather than being invested in lifting people out of abject poverty, malnutrition, and disease. He emphasized that 2005 should be marked as a year of campaigning to "make poverty history.

British Stars Miss Out on Major Oscars

British aspirations for significant Oscar wins were thwarted as UK stars did not secure victories in the acting and directing categories. Despite receiving three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" did not win either the director or screenplay awards, and Imelda Staunton also went home empty-handed. Kate Winslet was outdone by Hilary Swank for Best Actress, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo did not win the awards for Best Supporting Actor. On a more positive note, the UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film award for her gritty drama "Wasp." Arnold, who hosted children's TV shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, described her win as "totally overwhelming." "Wasp" depicts the struggles of a single mother living on the breadline and triumphed over films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, renowned for her contribution to the 1970s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film featuring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter menaced by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the movie grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide, setting a record for independent films at that time. Hill's collaboration with Carpenter also extended to films like "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, she started her career as a production assistant and climbed the ranks to become an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. Hill was widely recognized as a trailblazing woman in the film industry, taking on roles in the 1970s predominantly held by men.

Research indicates that high-speed internet access is significantly boosting online self-expression. According to a report by the UK think tank Demos, a substantial segment of broadband users in Britain, approximately one-quarter, routinely upload content and manage personal websites. The report highlights how an always-on, fast internet connection is transforming internet usage patterns. Currently, over five million UK households have broadband, and this number continues to rise swiftly. The Demos report analyzed the influence of broadband on internet habits, revealing that more than half of the broadband users access the web before breakfast. Remarkably, one in five confessed to browsing the internet in the middle of the night. Most notably, the report asserts that broadband is propelling individuals toward more active online engagement.

Yukos Returns to U.S. Courts: The Russian oil and gas company, Yukos, is scheduled to appear in a U.S. court on Thursday in its ongoing battle for survival. Russian authorities are dismantling the firm to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax debt. In response, Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the U.S., aiming to leverage international business law to halt the enforced sale of its crucial oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. Despite these efforts, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to the state-owned oil company, Rosneft, following an auction that was disrupted. Yukos' legal team argues that this auction breached U.S. bankruptcy laws. The company and its principal shareholders have pledged to pursue legal action against any entity acquiring its assets, utilizing every possible legal avenue.

Voters are eagerly visiting the blog awards site as voting kicks off for the annual Bloggies, which honor the year's best blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts. Nominations were revealed on Sunday, though the influx of traffic temporarily overwhelmed the official site, causing it to go offline. Blogs have been nominated across 30 categories, ranging from the best regional blog to the most under-the-radar blog. This has been a landmark year for blogs, with a major U.S. dictionary naming "blog" as the Word of the Year for 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors approximately six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 new ones are created each day. In fact, according to the U.S. research think tank Pew Internet & American Life, a new blog is launched every 5.8 seconds. However, fewer than 40% of all blogs are updated at least once every two months.

A Chinese dam company is reportedly defying Beijing's directives, according to the state press. The China Three Gorges Project Corporation has refused to halt construction on one of its massive dams, as ordered by the government. The firm, known for building the Three Gorges Dam, is pressing ahead with work on the Xiluodu Dam, as reported by the Beijing News. This dam is among 30 extensive construction projects that authorities have suspended due to inadequate environmental assessments. The Beijing News suggests that the company might opt to pay a fine instead of ceasing work. Additionally, the corporation has disregarded orders to stop construction on two other projects: the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. To date, only 22 out of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for neglecting required environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown order.

Manchester City 0-2 Manchester United: Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a hard-fought victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney connected with Gary Neville's cross at the near post, and his low shot, deflected off Richard Dunne, gave United the lead. Just seven minutes later, the unlucky Dunne inadvertently volleyed over David James' head, scoring an own goal. Steve McManaman squandered City's best opportunity, missing the target from just three yards out in the first half. During the opening 45 minutes, United seemed unlikely to clinch the victory needed to stay in the title race against Chelsea. Their play lacked urgency and focus, resulting in only one clear chance—a Paul Scholes header that sailed over the bar.

The new Health Minister for Wales, Dr. Brian Gibbons, emphasized the importance of learning from England's approach to managing waiting lists. On his first official day in the role following the dismissal of Jane Hutt, Dr. Gibbons acknowledged the "significant challenges" ahead but maintained that the fundamental components were already in place. Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, however, argued that Dr. Gibbons should implement policy changes. In her defense, Ms. Hutt highlighted that waiting times and lists constituted "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, who previously worked as a GP in Blaengwynfi, Upper Afan Valley, before serving as an AM for Aberavon, noted that NHS staff were seeking a phase of stabilization after extensive changes and reforms. One of the major issues Ms. Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half-year tenure as the Assembly's inaugural Health Minister was the prolonged waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson Applauds Manchester United's Tenacity

Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has lauded his team's determined performance in their 1-0 victory against Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away match of the season, and it turned out to be an outstanding football game, with relentless action and impressive passing," remarked the Old Trafford manager. "Our team displayed immense character and determination; we were not going to lose." 

Reflecting on the fixture, Ferguson added, "I think about this match and realize we've conquered it, whereas Arsenal and Chelsea are still yet to play Villa, who may have some key players returning by then." 

Ferguson also commended veteran players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who substituted for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and added the composure to our midfield that we desperately needed—something no other player can provide.

A new documentary offering an intimate glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael is set to premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Titled "A Different Story," the documentary will be featured in the festival's Panorama section, which takes place from February 10 to 20. The film highlights Michael discussing both his career and personal experiences, from his early days in Wham! to his more recent endeavors. Michael himself will attend the festival to present the screening on February 16. Joining him will be director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. Spanning 93 minutes, the documentary delves into Michael's journey, covering topics from his initial success with Wham! to later career challenges, including his legal disputes with Sony Records, and his outspoken views on the Iraq War and American politics.

Digital music downloads have been incorporated into the main U.S. singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now includes digital download sales data, which were previously only part of a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two on Billboard's pop chart and leads the digital chart. The U.K. singles chart plans to include download sales later this year. In the U.S., digital sales are already used to create Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. Now, these digital sales will be combined with physical single sales and airplay figures to form the new Hot 100 chart. Additionally, the new Pop 100 chart merges airplay and sales data but limits airplay information to U.S. radio stations that play chart-topping music.

Anti-spam laws have significantly impacted a notorious spammer, prompting the internet's self-proclaimed "spam king" to seek bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the mastermind behind OptInRealBig.com and responsible for billions of unsolicited emails, disclosed that legal challenges had pushed the company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. OptInRealBig has been embroiled in various legal conflicts, most prominently with Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company believes that filing for Chapter 11 will aid in addressing its legal issues while allowing it to continue operating. Recognized as the third largest spammer globally by the junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig faced a lawsuit in December 2003 for sending emails that breached anti-spam regulations. The legal action was initiated by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who accused Richter and his associates of disseminating billions of spam emails using 514 compromised internet addresses across 35 countries.

Frank Arnesen, Tottenham's sporting director, has dismissed claims of a rift with coach Jacques Santini, asserting that Santini's resignation was not due to any personality clash at White Hart Lane. Media outlets had suggested Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's influence within the club. Arnesen refuted these reports in an interview with BBC Radio Five Live, stating, "It is absolutely not true. The sole reason for his resignation is his personal issues." Arnesen mentioned that Santini had discussed the matter with him, emphasizing that it was a personal issue. Arnesen admitted he couldn't shed light on the specific problems that led Santini to step down after only 13 games. He added, "Jacques has never elaborated on the exact reasons, but I trust him, and it's important to respect his decision.

Ireland surged past Scotland, keeping their Six Nations Grand Slam hopes alive with a commanding victory at Murrayfield. Despite an initial setback when Hugo Southwell's try gave Scotland an early 8-0 lead, Ireland responded through outstanding efforts from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell, taking control by halftime. Wing Denis Hickie added a third try, and Ronan O'Gara’s precise kicking, contributing 13 points, further extended their advantage. Although Jon Petrie managed a second try for Scotland, late scores by John Hayes and Gavin Duffy secured Ireland's win. With two hard-fought away victories under their belt, Eddie O'Sullivan's squad now eagerly anticipates hosting England at Lansdowne Road in two weeks. Meanwhile, Scotland aims to secure Matt Williams his first Six Nations victory when they face Italy in Edinburgh, but they continue to struggle to convert pressure into points.

The economic future of Britain will be the central focus of Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced. He spoke following the cabinet's final meeting at No 10 before the anticipated election announcement. Brown asserted that voters would recognize Labour's role in achieving stability and growth, promising to maintain these achievements. Meanwhile, the Tories unveiled their strategies to combat "yob culture," and the Liberal Democrats provided further details on their proposals to reform council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury sent a letter to all three parties, urging them not to leverage people's fears during the election. In this open letter, he appealed to the parties to refrain from turning the election into a contest over who can most effectively frighten voters with concerns about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Paul Brizzel to Compete in AAA's Championships in Sheffield

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland’s hopefuls for the European Indoor Championships as he competes in this weekend’s AAA's Championships. U.S.-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not participate in Sheffield. Brizzel is set to defend his 200m title during the British trials. Meanwhile, James McIlroy, who is in excellent form, is aiming to secure his spot on the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has performed spectacularly on the European circuit in recent weeks, establishing himself as one of the fastest 800m runners globally this winter, and already appears well-positioned for selection in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg at the European Championships. Carroll is currently ranked third in the world in the 3000m, with Cragg holding the top position.

Jason Robinson is aiming for a remarkable dual code victory when England’s rugby union team, led by him, faces off against Australia this Saturday. Robinson, who transitioned from rugby league to rugby union in 2000, will captain the union side against Australia at Twickenham at 2:30 PM GMT. Later, at 6:15 PM GMT, Great Britain’s rugby league team will challenge Australia in the Tri-Nations tournament final. "Achieving wins over the Australians in both matches would be an incredible feat, especially for rugby league," Robinson remarked. England is poised to secure a third consecutive autumn international victory, having previously defeated Canada and South Africa, while also seeking redemption from a 51-15 loss to the Wallabies in June. Concurrently, Great Britain has the opportunity to break a 34-year winless streak against Australia with a triumph at Elland Road.

Internet users are being warned to steer clear of a fraudulent website that falsely claims to collect donations for tsunami victims. This deceptive site appears convincing as it mimics an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with the counterfeit site and has reported it to the police. This site is merely the latest in a series of scams exploiting the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The website's link is distributed through a spam email that is currently making the rounds. The email's subject line reads "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal," and the message features the poor grammar and spelling typical of many phishing schemes.

Iraq plans to invite bids for two telephone licenses as part of its strategy to significantly enhance nationwide telecommunications coverage over the next ten years. According to Iraq's Ministry of Communications, bids are open to local, Arab, and international companies. The selected company will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to establish and manage a fixed phone network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's currently low telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to about 25% within a decade. Additionally, they aspire to develop a telecommunications sector that is both prominent and adaptable. Detailed information on the bidding and tender process will be available on the ministry's website on February 9. Furthermore, a roadshow for potential investors is planned in Amman, Jordan.

An increasing number of women and older individuals are taking the initiative to safeguard their home computers against online threats, as highlighted by a two-year study. Between 2002 and 2004, the percentage of women purchasing software to defend PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware increased by 11.2% annually. The research, conducted for the internet security company Preventon, indicates that security awareness is spreading to a broader audience of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those acquiring home internet security software are retirees. Over the past three years, this figure has risen by an average of 13.2%. Interestingly, more retired women (53%) are buying security software compared to their male counterparts. This study underscores the shift in the typical profile and demographics of internet users along with a heightened awareness of the risks associated with high-speed broadband connections.

Podcasts represent the emergence of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can store up to 10,000 songs, offering ample space to fill. Increasingly, iPod users are filling this space with audio content produced by a diverse range of creators. This trend, known as "podcasting," has found a prominent advocate in former MTV host and video jockey Adam Curry. The term podcasting derives from the Apple iPod, but you don't need an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show often produced by podcasters in the comfort of their own homes. All they require is a microphone, a computer, and some editing software. Once the shows are uploaded to the internet, they are freely available for others to download and enjoy.

Andrea Levy, previously recognized for her Orange Prize win, has now claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book "Small Island." She has emerged as the frontrunner for the overall prize, having surpassed Booker Prize winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." Meanwhile, Geraldine McCaughrean has secured the Children's Fiction Award for the third time with "Not the End of the World." All category winners will vie for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which offers a £25,000 prize. Judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, are set to convene on January 25 to decide the overall winner, with the result to be announced that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has positioned London's Levy as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos plans to return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure entity that purchased its main asset. Yukos announced its intention to sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. Yukos' American legal team will aim to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government disregarded a U.S. court order last week that sought to block the sale. The origins of Baikal and the reasons behind its acquisition of the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have reported that Baikal, which acquired the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) on Sunday during a state-induced auction, has substantial connections to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final clash, scoring two decisive goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring within the first minute, heading the ball over Colin Meldrum into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister added the second goal himself, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, effectively sealing the game for the home team. Although Craig Easton managed a contentious goal for Livingston after an hour, Hearts maintained their lead. The opening goal resulted from Gus Bahoken's reckless foul on Miller 35 yards from goal, allowing McAllister to deliver a free kick into the box, where Miller outleaped the stationary defense to head it in from 10 yards out. Just ten minutes in, Hearts extended their lead as Mikoliunas raced down the right flank and crossed to the back post, where McAllister dashed in to head the ball past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a new pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers to rent significant computing power on an hourly basis. The Sun Grid service charges users $1 (53p) per hour for access to processing and storage power on Sun-managed systems. This concept of grid computing represents a modern trend, likened to the evolution of electricity, positioning computing capacity as a critical commodity alongside hardware and software. Jonathan Schwartz, Sun's Chief Operating Officer, highlighted this parallel, suggesting grid computing might evolve similarly to essential utilities like electricity and water. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for just a dollar an hour?" he posed during a webcast at Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California.

Jamieson Issues Warning to Bigoted Fans

Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, expressing her intent to strike them "where it hurts most" by implementing bans from attending matches. She noted that exclusion orders are among several strategies under consideration by the Scottish Executive in their effort to combat sectarianism. Jamieson commended Celtic and Rangers for their proactive efforts in addressing the issue. Nevertheless, she emphasized that eliminating sectarian abuse tied to Old Firm matches remains a primary goal. The minister made her remarks in anticipation of the Scottish Cup third-round showdown between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead this Sunday. Sectarianism, historically linked to factions of both clubs' supporters, has become a crucial focus for the Executive. Last week, Jamieson, alongside First Minister Jack McConnell, met with supporter representatives from both clubs to discuss the matter.

Kevin Spacey Movie Makes UK Debut

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth graced the British premiere of their new film, "Beyond the Sea," on Thursday at London’s Leicester Square. Spacey, 45, took on multiple roles in the project, serving as the writer, director, and star of the movie, which is inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This film is my tribute to someone I consider to be an extraordinary talent," said Spacey, who performs all 18 songs on the soundtrack in his portrayal of Darin. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I’m a huge fan," shared Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds vs. Saracens (Friday) at Headingley - Friday, 25 February, 20:00 GMT. The Tykes have secured Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is set to play as hooker for Saracens, marking one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell have also been added to the pack, with Kevin Sorrell stepping in at outside centre.  Friday's match at Headingley was confirmed after successfully passing an early pitch inspection. 

Leeds lineup: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (captain), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

The future of home phones is becoming increasingly uncertain, with the traditional fixed-line phones in households potentially on the verge of becoming obsolete. A study conducted by handset manufacturer Nokia indicates that a growing number of people rely exclusively on their mobile phones for all their calls. The research found that over 45 million individuals in countries like the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now use only mobile phones. The study highlighted that although fixed-line phones are kept because of their lower call charges, the majority of participants viewed mobile phones as the future. The Nokia-sponsored study also revealed distinct usage patterns between mobile and fixed-line phones. Home phones are typically used for longer conversations, while mobiles are favored for shorter calls, often made between mobiles and to friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents mentioned that they prefer using their fixed-line phones due to the lower cost compared to mobile phones.

MPs Advocate for House of Lords Reform Plan

A group of MPs is intensifying efforts to pressure Tony Blair into reforming the House of Lords by releasing a comprehensive blueprint for change. This cross-party group has introduced a draft bill that envisages a restructured second chamber, with 70% of its members being elected. Since 1999, MPs and peers have struggled to agree on reforms after 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group believes it can garner support to eliminate the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government had delayed plans to remove these hereditary peers due to anticipated opposition in the Lords, making success unlikely. Tony Blair has emphasized the necessity for consensus on reforms. It has been speculated that Labour's manifesto will include proposals to alter at least the powers of the Lords.

Allan Scott, despite experiencing some disappointment, is feeling optimistic about his chances of winning a medal at the upcoming European Indoor Championships following a promising start on the international stage. The 22-year-old athlete from Scotland achieved a commendable fourth place in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial meeting in Madrid. "It was certainly a learning experience, and I am still very much in the running for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride native. The race saw Felipe Vivancos taking first place while matching the Spanish record, followed by Sweden's Robert Kronberg in second and Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Although Scott was somewhat dissatisfied with his performance in the final, having clocked a winning time of 7.64 seconds in his heat, he ran slightly slower by 0.04 seconds in the final of his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit.

A woman in the United States has filed a lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard (HP), claiming that its printer ink cartridges are designed to expire on a set date.
