The plaintiff, a resident of Georgia, alleges that a chip within the cartridge signals the printer to request a refill even when it is not necessary. The legal action aims to include all U.S. consumers who have purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the leading printer manufacturer globally, has declined to comment on the case. The company’s ink cartridges employ chip technology to detect low ink levels and inform users when a change is needed. However, the lawsuit asserts that these chips also deactivate the cartridges at a predetermined time, irrespective of their ink status.

Virgin Radio to Launch 3G Broadcasts

UK broadcaster Virgin Radio has announced that it will become the first station globally to offer radio via 3G mobile networks. Collaborating with technology firm Sydus, the station will provide broadcasts on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download software from the Virgin website to access this service. James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, stated, "This initiative places radio at the core of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the inaugural station available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland emphasized, "This application will allow anyone, anywhere to tune into Virgin Radio using just the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music Set to Perform at Isle of Wight Festival

Roxy Music will make an appearance at June's Isle of Wight Music Festival, sharing the stage with acts like Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been announced as the headliners for this three-day event, scheduled from June 10th to 12th. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson are slated to perform on Saturday night. In addition to their live performance, the band is currently in the studio working on new material—their first since the 1982 album "Avalon." Roxy Music was founded in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining a year later. Their initial hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," followed by other renowned tracks such as "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's "Jealous Guy.

Captains Set to Participate in Aid Match: Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is among four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid Match on March 5. Joining him are France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami relief match at Twickenham. "I'm eager to work with such exceptional players," Woodward commented. This match will provide Woodward with an opportunity to evaluate his options before announcing the British and Irish Lions touring team, which is scheduled to visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a spectacular event," he added.

The film "Sideways" has taken center stage at this year's Independent Spirit Awards, securing victories in all six categories it contended for. It was honored as Best Film, while Alexander Payne, alongside his writing partner Jim Taylor, clinched the awards for Best Director and Best Screenplay. The film's lead actors, Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen, also received acting accolades. "Sideways" is anticipated to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, where it has garnered five nominations. Celebrating its 20th anniversary, the Spirit Awards spotlight films produced outside the conventional studio framework and traditionally occur the day prior to the Oscars. Among other notable winners, Catalina Sandino Moreno received the Best Actress award for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award was conferred to Joshua Marston for "Maria Full of Grace.

In 2004, Prince was named the top-earning music artist, surpassing icons like Madonna and Elton John according to Rolling Stone's annual list. He amassed $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from his Musicology tour and album, outperforming Madonna, who came in second with $54.9 million (£29.5 million) from her global Re-Invention Tour. Meanwhile, Simon and Garfunkel ranked tenth, earning $24.9 million (£13.4 million) with their comeback tour. Rolling Stone highlighted Prince's triumphant return to the spotlight after a decade away from the commercial mainstream. His 2004 tour alone generated $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales and he sold 1.9 million copies of his album "Musicology.

The Tories have unveiled plans that would allow local communities to elect their own regional police commissioners, as proposed by the Conservative Party. Party leader Michael Howard stated that this new position would replace what he described as "inconspicuous" police authorities. He emphasized that the role would not override the responsibilities of a chief constable. In response, the Liberal Democrats expressed concerns that such a plan might enable extremist groups to influence policing, while the Labour Party criticized the Tories' "extravagant" promises regarding law enforcement. Additionally, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, Jan Berry, which represents rank-and-file officers, highlighted the importance of maintaining operational independence. She remarked, "Policing is a service, not a political football to be manipulated during election periods. These proposals could lead to scenarios where those with extreme political views dictate on-the-ground actions," she cautioned.

Overview: Conservative Health Check Proposal

The UK's opposition Conservative party has unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they secure victory in the general election. Here's an overview of their proposal:

- The plan targets individuals intending to live and work in Britain who are arriving from outside the European Union.
- Those planning to stay for six months or longer, and arriving from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis (TB), would be required to undergo a chest X-ray and further examinations if deemed necessary.
- All non-EU nationals planning to remain for a year or more would need to undergo a comprehensive medical examination.
- Tests would screen for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV.
- A positive tuberculosis test would automatically result in the rejection of visa applications.
- Other medical conditions would be assessed on an individual basis.

The Paris triumph has sparked hope among Welsh fans. Is there a more thrilling Six Nations match than Saturday's unforgettable clash in Paris? And can the Welsh resurgence continue to claim their first Grand Slam since 1978? These are the pressing questions not just for Welsh supporters, but for rugby fans everywhere, following a spectacular performance in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of the three Grand Slam-winning teams of the 1970s, acclaimed it as "one of the greatest performances of the past thirty years." Martyn Williams, who scored two tries for Wales that day, described it as "one of the most surreal games I've ever played." A dejected French coach, Bernard Laporte, simply noted: "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half.

The Manchester rock band Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart, debuting at number one with their latest release, "Some Cities." This achievement sees them overtake the vibrant US group Scissor Sisters for the top spot. Their album's success follows the single "Black and White Town," which climbed to number six on the charts. Meanwhile, R&B artist Nelly has captured the number one position on the singles chart with "Over and Over," a collaboration with Tim McGraw. New entries in the top ten singles include tracks from Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs, as well as contributions from Futureheads and Usher. The newest Elvis Presley re-release, "(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame," makes a strong entry at number three, just one slot above Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up." The hip-hop artist Akon's "Locked Up" holds the fifth position, while the promising Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs secure their second chart presence at number six with "Oh My God.

Mefin Davies, potentially the future hooker for Wales, is expected to remain with the English team Gloucester, despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. Sources from BBC Wales indicate that while the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, Davies prefers to stay with his current team. Davies, a standout performer in Saturday’s RBS Six Nations victory over England, is currently on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, he has showcased his value to the Zurich Premiership side, making a new contract likely for the next season. The dissolution of the Celtic Warriors region last summer left Davies in a difficult position, leading him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he received playing time with the Ospreys at the behest of the Welsh management, Davies revealed before his move to Gloucester that he was upset with how he was treated.

Cabinet Discontent Over Brown's Cash Reallocation

There is dissatisfaction among ministers concerning plans to divert Whitehall funds to offset council tax bills, as confirmed by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. In Thursday's pre-budget report, Gordon Brown reassigned £512 million from central to local government budgets. Mr. Raynsford mentioned having had some "very candid discussions" with colleagues about these plans. However, he stressed that local governments must provide quality services without imposing significant council tax increases. The central government funds are part of a £1 billion initiative intended to assist local authorities in England in maintaining council tax hikes below 5% in the forthcoming year, which is expected to be an election year. According to Mr. Raynsford, nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in efficiently managed local authorities.

The Israeli club is turning its attention to Africa, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, ready to play for Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is making history as the first Arab team to compete in European competitions, facing English Premier League team Newcastle United in the opening round. Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a crucial role in Bnei Sakhnin’s 6-1 victory over Albania’s Partizani Tirana in the previous round. He recently moved to Israel following a brief period with South African club Hellenic. Last season, the club won the Israeli Cup final and it is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. Bnei Sakhnin is dedicated to promoting peace and cooperation in Israel through its strong ethical framework.

A recent report suggests that reducing drink-drive limits by a third could save more lives than previously estimated. Research from University College London indicates that lowering the alcohol limit from 80mg to 50mg per 100ml of blood could prevent 65 fatalities annually. These findings are being released by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. Although the bill proposes changes to speeding fines, it does not address the drink-drive limit. Conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, the research indicates that this reduction could result in 230 fewer serious road injuries in the UK, compared to figures from 2003, and could save the country £119 million each year. Previously, a 1998 Department of Transport document had estimated that such a measure could save 50 lives annually.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode is employed to measure the energy deposited by a single charged particle within the depletion region. The array offers a substantial detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of detecting the voltage drop due to radiation, the system captures the pulse width, which is the duration for the voltage to return to its baseline. This approach eliminates the need for power-intensive and bulky analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC has been fabricated using the TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, with an average static power consumption of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The entire system's functionality is successfully validated in a clinical setting using a 67.5 MeV proton beam.

The ability to control the routing of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to mitigate the negative effects of selfish routing on overall network efficiency. However, the expectation that AVs would willingly accept external control from a central authority is not realistic. In this paper, we introduce an integrated routing and pricing control strategy designed to motivate AVs to adopt centrally managed, system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings. Meanwhile, AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) aiming for user equilibrium (UE) are charged a congestion fee. This issue is addressed through bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, and the lower level constitutes a mixed equilibrium, simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model that accounts for a fleet comprising both AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature-squeezed states, and entangled motion states. Beyond advancing larger and more tangible objects into the realm of quantum behavior, this capability has spurred ideas for using mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, and as precision force sensors that surpass the standard quantum limit. However, the essentially linear interaction between motion and light or electricity limits access to a broader range of quantum motion states, such as cat states or energy-squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested that this limitation could be overcome by achieving strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. Although experiments have demonstrated quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, they have not yet achieved nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews are crucial for customers making informed purchasing decisions, but they are often compromised by fake reviews, or "spam," posted by skilled spammers. These spammers develop increasingly sophisticated and effective methods to bypass existing detection systems. Detecting spam is challenging because these strategies evolve rapidly over time, vary among spammers and targeted products, and remain largely unknown. Moreover, most detection systems emphasize accuracy without adequately supporting the broader objective of maintaining the reliability of product evaluations. To tackle these challenges, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and detectors engage in a strategic competition, focusing on pragmatic goals beyond mere detection accuracy. At the game's Nash equilibria, we find detectors that remain robust and resilient, irrespective of varying detection strategies.

We have developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer within a 3-level quantum system configured in a lambda setup. To maintain high fidelity, we apply the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions that enable exact transfer, aligning with a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution characterized by a single parameter that simultaneously controls the transfer fidelity, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define robustness for an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimal percentile deviation in pulse areas where infidelity exceeds $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses exhibit superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we explore the properties of the population's negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with any number of components. Owing to their non-convex nature, these models possess multiple local minima that do not equate to global optima, even if the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima exhibit a similar structural pattern, which partially reveals the true mixture's component centers. Specifically, each local minimum represents either the fitting of multiple Gaussians to a single true component or a single Gaussian to multiple true components without overlap. Our findings pertain to scenarios in which the true mixture components adhere to a specific separation condition and remain applicable irrespective of whether the number of components is overestimated or underestimated. For Gaussian mixtures comprising three components, we derive more precise results in terms of how they scale with the component separation.

We examine the relationship between two approaches for constructing the mirror partner of a Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as the quotient by an appropriate subgroup \( g \) of the phase symmetries of a hypersurface \( x_m \) in weighted projective space, characterized by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( w_m \). The first method, known as the Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, employs another weighted projective space and considers the quotient of a new hypersurface \( x_{m^t} \) within that space by a dual group \( g^t \). In the second approach, the Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is developed as a hypersurface within a toric variety, defined by the reflexive polytope that is dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We present straightforward evidence supporting the equivalence of these two constructions.

This study presents a generalization of human gait analysis based on existing models from the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. The proposed hybrid model integrates a strategy for minimizing metabolic energy with a nonlinear approach to describing the center of mass's movement, aiming to simulate the walk-run transition. Experimental data across various speed regimes suggest that the trajectory's perimeter of the center of mass plays a significant role in quantifying this dynamic. The experimental procedure was conducted in partnership with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We introduce a novel mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator designed for simulating planetary systems, with a particular ability to accurately handle close encounters. This approach employs a time regularization technique that maintains the stability of symplectic integrators while dynamically reducing the effective time step during planetary encounters. Our method utilizes a high-order MVS scheme, enabling the use of large time steps when planets are distant from each other. This ensures that our algorithm can handle almost direct collisions—defined as situations with mutual separation being a fraction of the physical radius—using time steps similar to those in mildly perturbed systems like the solar system. We illustrate its long-term effectiveness in systems consisting of six super-Earths undergoing significant scattering over 50,000 years. Compared to hybrid methods such as MERCURY, our algorithm achieves superior energy conservation at a comparable computational cost.

Entanglement is a crucial asset in quantum information processing. A commonly utilized method for identifying entanglement is the entanglement witness, which ensures that the measurement of the witness operator remains positive for all separable states and may become negative for specific entangled states. In practice, the exponentially increasing Hilbert space dimension relative to system size poses significant challenges in developing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness method requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can withstand up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only necessitates two local measurement settings while enduring up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within the framework of general relativity, the Kerr spacetime describes the distinct stationary solution for an isolated black hole, characterized by a unique multipolar structure dictated solely by the black hole's mass and spin. We have devised a comprehensive method to determine the multipole moments of any stationary spacetime and applied it to a wide array of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can disrupt the axial and equatorial symmetry found in the Kerr metric, resulting in a more complex multipolar structure. This complexity serves as a key to phenomenologically constrain fuzzball models. Our numerical findings suggest that the multipole moments in these cases are generally greater (in absolute terms) than those associated with a Kerr black hole of identical mass and spin. Present assessments of the quadrupole moment for black-hole candidates offer minimal constraints on fuzzball theories, yet future gravitational-wave observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals, such as those anticipated with the LISA space mission, have the potential to significantly refine these limits.

Reasoning about the evolution of graphs over time is a complex concept in various fields, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We focus on a common scenario where edges represent either short-term interactions (like messaging) or long-term structural connections (such as friendships). Typically, long-term edges are determined by humans, which can be costly to produce and may not be optimal for downstream tasks. To address these challenges, we introduce a model that leverages temporal point processes and variational autoencoders to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing their communication. By learning this temporal attention through the dynamics of node interactions, we enhance flexibility in feature propagation between nodes and simultaneously bypass the limitations associated with human-defined edges.

The study presents observations of thermally induced transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW). The waveguide is composed of two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Developed models have been validated for converting beam movements into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe traveling in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW, applicable both when probe frequencies are distant from and near the dielectric band edge. Given that this PCW is designed for near-field atom trapping, the research lays the groundwork for assessing potential negative impacts of thermal motion on optical atomic traps located close to PCW surfaces. The long-term objectives include establishing robust atom-mediated interactions between individual vibrational phonons and single photons traveling in the waveguide's GMs, thus facilitating quantum-level opto-mechanical interactions involving atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural decompositions for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Notably, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of neighboring dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The significance of these splittings is linked to equivariant stable homotopy theory. Since the equivariant stable homotopy groups of any global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, this splitting indicates that certain long exact sequences of homotopy groups break down into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra, denoted as $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, these splittings suggest the regularity of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects cause a reduction in the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. This suppression, with its uncertain shape and magnitude, presents a significant source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys like Euclid and LSST. In this first paper of a two-part series, we utilize simulations to create a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and its associated covariance matrix. Both are adjusted for baryonic effects, based on the baryonification method by Schneider et al. (2019). Furthermore, we develop an emulator that provides rapid predictions of baryonic power suppression, enabling us to conduct a likelihood inference analysis within a standard ΛCDM cosmology, incorporating both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world scenarios, particularly those captured in child-centered recordings, have proven to be some of the most difficult audio files to process. Despite these challenges, developing speech processing models that can handle a broad range of conditions is crucial for language acquisition research. Such models are essential for researchers interested in analyzing the quantity and quality of speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and assessing the effects of remediation. In this paper, we introduce our method for creating an open-source neural network designed to classify audio segments. These segments include vocalizations made by the child wearing the recording device, other children's vocalizations, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we compiled diverse child-centered corpora totaling 260 hours of recordings across 10 different languages.

Density-based clustering is centered around connecting clusters to specific features of the underlying probability distribution of the data. By acknowledging an actual, yet unknown, population structure, clustering can be approached through standard inferential methodologies. Here, the notion of an ideal population cluster is characterized by the partition dictated by the true density function. This approach, particularly its nonparametric form known as modal clustering, aligns the groups with the domains of attraction around the density modes. Practically, it requires a nonparametric density estimate, and skillful smoothing is vital, as it influences the shape of the density and potentially the modal structure, to accurately determine the final partition. In our study, we tackle the challenge of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic standpoint.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are crucial for detecting the interference between the Standard Model and higher-dimension operators that represent the influence of new, heavy physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes introduce a barrier to the straightforward interference contributions from dimension-six operators, leading to the cancellation of the leading contribution to the total diboson rate correction. In this scenario, a precise measurement of the azimuthal decay angles effectively "revives" the interference, restoring sensitivity to these "non-interfering" operators. In our detailed exploration of these signatures, we discover that the Effective Field Theory (EFT) uncertainties tied to higher-dimensional operators are uniquely mitigated by the development of an asymmetry variable, which is exclusively produced by these non-interfering operators. As a result, the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators are demoted to the same level as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a key objective in many data analyses within the health and social sciences. Traditionally, academic statistics has been skeptical of data analyses aimed at drawing causal conclusions. However, the advent of the term "data science" presents a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis, enabling it to naturally integrate causal inference from observational data. Like others have previously, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three major task classes: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which encompasses causal inference). Clearly defining these data science tasks is essential for discussing the data, assumptions, and analytical methods needed to successfully complete each task. We contend that the often overlooked role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a significant source of widespread misconceptions about data science.

The Weak Gravity Conjecture (WGC) asserts that superextremal particles must exist within any coherent quantum theory of gravity. It is traditionally understood that these particles play a crucial role in ensuring that extremal black holes are either unstable or at best marginally stable. However, the implications of their absence are not well understood. This document demonstrates that, within a typical Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, the exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with established quantum information theorems concerning entanglement entropy. To resolve this contradiction, a nonperturbative version of the WGC is proposed, aligning with the conventional assertion at weak coupling. This argument is broad and does not depend on supersymmetry or any specific UV completion; it only presumes the legitimacy of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

One of the key unresolved challenges in condensed matter physics is understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can lead to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as pristine and controllable model systems to explore the interaction between strong correlations and reduced dimensionality. However, direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. In this study, we demonstrate superfluidity within an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing the absence of dissipation below a critical velocity, denoted as \(v_{\rm c}\). We measure \(v_{\rm c}\) as a function of interaction strength and identify a peak in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our findings establish ultracold Fermi gases as a potent tool for investigating the effects of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) serve as essential mathematical models across numerous fields, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to their intuitive approach to modeling complex phenomena. Despite their widespread application, ODEs often lack analytic solutions, posing challenges in parameter estimation from data, particularly in models with numerous variables and parameters. This paper introduces a Bayesian algorithm for estimating ODE parameters, which is both fast and accurate, even for models with a large number of parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model using a state-space model derived from the equations of a numerical solver. This approach facilitates rapid estimation by eliminating the need to compute an entire numerical solution within the likelihood. The posterior distribution is obtained through a variational Bayes method, specifically employing the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method as detailed by Honkela et al.

In our research, we explore the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions that arise when a Weyl semimetal with broken time-reversal symmetry is in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. Our findings reveal that both the differential conductance and the induced pairing amplitudes are significantly influenced by the angle between the direction of the junction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We also highlight the impact of a chiral chemical potential, which refers to the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the junction's transport features. Interestingly, we detect a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection within the two Weyl semimetal regions. This spin polarization is opposite in the two regions and is highly sensitive to variations in chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics is a proven and precise technique for modifying the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic materials, and has been applied successfully in various contexts. This method is particularly noteworthy for its ability to control the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby enhancing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied without causing surface flashover. A potential issue in utilizing this technique is the stability of the implantation-induced conductivity over time, primarily if the implanted metal is prone to oxidation. In our study, we investigate the long-term stability of surface conductivity in titanium-implanted alumina. Our findings reveal that while there is an initial reduction in conductivity of up to 40% within the first few weeks post-implantation, the rate of decrease markedly slows, with only about a 10% reduction observed over the subsequent year.

We present an innovative Skyrme-like conserved current within the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, grounded in the concept of hidden local symmetry. The corresponding charge aligns with the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Additionally, there are singular configurations identifiable as \( n_f=1 \) baryons, which carry a charge under this new symmetry. In this framework, vector mesons serve as Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the \( n_f=1 \) baryon. We propose that this current accurately represents the baryon current at low energies, offering a unified perspective on the two baryon types and facilitating their seamless transformation into one another. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a consequence of a Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions provides an intriguing opportunity to merge anomalous Hall effects with Josephson physics within a single device. Our theoretical study explores how these combined effects influence the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface results in significant transverse Hall supercurrents, termed anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, originally developed to measure conventional (tunneling) Josephson current flows, to assess the transverse current components. We demonstrate that their amplitudes can be significantly adjusted by altering spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinct spectroscopic signature of these Josephson junctions, well-defined subgap bound states emerge around the interface.

Building on insights from the Monte Carlo experiments detailed in Jiménez, J. (J. of Turbul., 2020), which highlight the critical role of dipoles in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence, alongside individual vortex cores, it is observed that the flow's kinetic energy is predominantly carried by elongated streams formed by linked dipoles. Vortices divide into two groups: smaller, fast-moving cores and larger, slow-moving ones. The larger cores can be considered as 'frozen' within a gradually evolving 'crystal.' The kinematics of these two groups differ significantly, with only the smaller cores demonstrating self-similar behavior. The larger group drives the primary kinetic energy of the flow, forming the dipoles and streams. The mechanisms for the development of this slower component are explored further.

Continuous-time quantum walks have emerged as an immensely valuable framework for developing various quantum algorithms. A key measure in this framework is the quantum hitting time, which determines the time needed for a quantum walk to locate a target vertex with high probability. In this article, we establish enhanced upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to numerous quantum algorithms based on continuous-time quantum walks. Specifically, our methods enhance the solution to the glued-trees problem by reducing the upper bound on hitting time from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$—a significant polynomial reduction. Additionally, our techniques achieve an exponential improvement in precision dependence for the continuous-time quantum walk algorithm to identify a marked node within any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, as demonstrated by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized into two types, dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs, depending on how they form. Previously, dry EMRIs, also known as "loss-cone" EMRIs, were considered the primary EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna. These are mainly generated by multi-body interactions and gravitational capture in nuclear star clusters. In this letter, we explore an alternative formation pathway for EMRIs: the formation of wet EMRIs, facilitated by the accretion flow around accreting massive black holes (MBHs) in galactic centers. In this scenario, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially on inclined orbits, prompting them to migrate toward the MBH. This process significantly enhances the EMRI formation rate in such galaxies by several orders of magnitude.

When a new user registers on a website, we typically lack any information about them, meaning no interactions with items, no user profile, and no social connections with other users. Despite this, we still aim for our recommender systems to engage users on their first visit, encouraging them to remain on the site and become active participants. This challenge is categorized as the new user cold-start problem, which is critical for a company's growth and even its survival. Current solutions for the user cold-start recommendation often demand extra efforts from users, like conducting an interview process, or rely on supplementary data, such as user demographics, locations, or social relationships, as noted in [10]. However, users may be reluctant to participate in interviews, and additional information about cold-start users is generally not accessible.

Deep learning has addressed numerous challenges beyond the scope of traditional heuristic algorithms. It has found successful applications in wireless communications, despite the current radio systems being well-understood, with optimal algorithms available for many tasks. Although some improvements have been achieved by focusing on individual components of a receiver, a more effective strategy is to learn the entire receiver system collectively. This approach, however, often leads to a complex nonlinear problem, making the optimal solution difficult to implement. In response, we have developed a deep fully convolutional neural network, named deeprx, which manages the entire receiver process—from processing the frequency domain signal stream to producing uncoded bits—in a manner compliant with 5G standards. To enhance the accuracy of channel estimation, we meticulously design the input for the convolutional neural network, incorporating both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing generally starts with a set of non-crashing seed inputs, known as a corpus, which serves as a basis for generating new inputs through mutation. Often, a corpus consists of thousands of similar inputs, which can limit diversity and result in inefficient fuzzing due to repetitive mutations from all available seeds. To combat this issue, fuzzers are equipped with distillation tools, such as afl-cmin, designed to pinpoint the smallest subset of seeds that can trigger the same range of instrumentation data points as the entire corpus. It is widely accepted that reducing the number and total size of these seeds enhances fuzzing efficiency, a hypothesis we systematically examine. We present the findings from over 34 CPU-years of fuzzing utilizing five different distillation techniques to assess their effectiveness in uncovering bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we explore multi-agent discrete-event systems with the challenge of partial observation. We categorize the agents into distinct groups, within which agents share similar (isomorphic) state transition structures. Consequently, they can be reconfigured into a unified template. Utilizing this template, we develop a scalable supervisor designed for partial observation scenarios. Notably, the state size and computational cost of this supervisor remain constant, regardless of the number of agents in the system. The scalable supervisor under partial observation is robust, eliminating the need for recalibration as agents are added or removed. We extend our prior work to address partial observation by introducing sufficient conditions that ensure both safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An example is included to demonstrate the proposed method for scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations offer a powerful tool for multimedia forensics. An innovative method for ENF estimation involves temporal windowing, utilizing the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. This technique employs a Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix, leveraging its Toeplitz structure. Notably, it introduces the use of a temporal window—other than the typical rectangular form—before the spectral estimation phase, marking a first in ENF analysis. Krylov matrices facilitate rapid matrix inversions for efficient implementation. When applied with a brief one-second time window in power recordings, this approach surpasses current state-of-the-art methods. In the context of speech recordings, it delivers exceptionally high accuracy and efficiency in terms of both time complexity and result precision.

The direpack package is designed to integrate a suite of contemporary statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python ecosystem, offering them as a unified and coherent package. It encompasses dimension reduction methods grouped into three main categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, the package includes regularized regression estimators derived from these reduced dimension spaces, extending from traditional principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. It also offers a collection of both classical and robust pre-processing tools, including generalized spatial signs, along with specialized plotting capabilities and cross-validation utilities. Consistent with the scikit-learn API, direpack ensures that its estimators can be seamlessly integrated into statistical and machine learning pipelines within that framework.

Nonlinear fluorescence emission has been extensively utilized for achieving high spatial resolution in optical imaging. In our study, we explored the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect associated with nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. When subjected to high-power laser excitation, a reduction in fluorescence was observed, which heightened the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altered the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. To extract high spatial frequency information, we implemented a differential excitation protocol. By modulating the power of the excitation laser, we were able to enhance the spatial resolution of imaging by approximately 1.6 times compared to traditional confocal microscopy. Owing to the simplicity of both the experimental setup and data processing, we anticipate that this method can be employed to enhance the spatial resolution in applications such as sensing and biological labeling using defects in solids.

When random effects correlate with sample design variables, using individual survey weights—which are designed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities—no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. To address this, we propose a weight-exponentiated model for the random effects distribution that successfully produces unbiased inference for deriving hyperparameters of the random effects. Our approach is compared to frequentist methods utilizing numerical integration, highlighting that only the Bayesian method achieves unbiased estimation relative to the sampling design distribution, while also maintaining consistency with the population-generating distribution. Through simulations and a real-world data example from a survey of business establishments, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our method across various modeling frameworks and sampling designs. This work culminates recent development efforts that integrate traditional survey estimation techniques with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, thereby connecting these two rich yet distinct fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—including monolayers of ReS$_2$, ReSe$_2$, black phosphorus, group-IV monochalcogenides, and borophene—exhibit far more intricate atomistic structures compared to the simpler honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. These materials' reduced symmetries lead to diverse and uneven electron, optical, valley, and spin responses. They also display unique properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, significant nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Furthermore, low symmetry can result in novel electronic topological traits, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was curated to bring attention to recent experimental and theoretical advancements in the study of these innovative materials.

The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. This study revealed, for the first time, that unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of electric birefringence in a mesogenic polymer melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by the sum of several exponential processes, with two being particularly significant. These primary processes shift in dominance across a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Through dielectric spectroscopy, researchers were able to identify two distinct orientational relaxation processes: the first resulting from the rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second linked to the movement of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing techniques have demonstrated remarkable retrieval efficiency and accuracy in large-scale image retrieval systems. The focus of deep hashing methods has always been on optimizing discrete hash codes. These methods typically employ an activation function—such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$—and aim to minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this approach can lead to an increasing number of hash bits getting stuck in the incorrect saturation zones of the activation functions, from which they cannot escape. We refer to this issue as the "dead bits problem" (dbp). Moreover, the traditional quantization loss can exacerbate dbp. In this paper, we introduce a straightforward yet effective solution: a gradient amplifier that operates before the activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We explore the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, which is hypothesized to exist due to the two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking process. Our study considers two scenarios: first, where these triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, and second, where they decay through mixing with the Standard Model Higgs boson. In the case of stable triplets, constraints arise from disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and direct detection dark matter experiments. For unstable triplets, existing multilepton collider search results provide limitations. We conclude that a two-step electroweak phase transition featuring a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection efforts, whereas an unstable triplet with a mass under 230 GeV is excluded with 95% confidence.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are surprisingly narrower than what is anticipated by the conventional eccentric planet perturbation model, often known as "pericenter glow." According to this traditional theory, a belt of planetesimals, initially circular and narrow with a semi-major axis $a$, attains an eccentricity $e_f$ following the dispersion of the gas disc due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet. This results in a belt with a width of $2ae_f$. A slight alteration to this scenario suggests that narrower belts may develop if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, a condition possibly arising from previous planet-induced perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, this initial eccentricity might be attributed to instabilities that increase the disc's eccentricity, eliminating the necessity for any planetary influence.

An electron is generally thought to possess a single type of kinetic energy, but could it also exhibit additional forms due to its spin, charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the behavior of interacting electrons is accurately described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-Liquid (TLL) model, yet experimental observations beyond this linear regime have been limited. In this study, we present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using a tunneling spectroscopy technique. We identify two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, corresponding to spin and charge excitations, along with the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that become more pronounced as the wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength in the wires is adjusted by altering the level of 1D inter-subband screening, achieving a variation of over 45%.

The Milky Way's assembly history is being progressively revealed through the insights gained from the Gaia mission. It is believed that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has undergone a similarly complex formation process. To better understand this formation path, our focus is on exploring the relationship between the globular clusters and the known merging events that have shaped the Milky Way. For this purpose, we merged the kinematic data from Gaia, covering nearly all galactic clusters, with a comprehensive dataset of cluster ages that have been meticulously adjusted for any systematic errors. By examining their dynamical properties, particularly within the framework of integrals of motion, we seek to identify clusters that share a common origin. Our findings indicate that approximately 40% of these clusters likely originated from within the galaxy itself.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a crucial step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces "intrinsic," an R package that provides cutting-edge, likelihood-based estimators for determining a dataset's intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package includes the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To ensure these advanced estimators are easily accessible, the package offers a range of high-level, user-friendly functions built upon a robust set of efficient, low-level routines. The package features models divided into two main categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The homogeneous category comprises the two-nn and gride models, with functions supporting inference under both frequentist and Bayesian paradigms. In the heterogeneous category, the hidalgo model is included, which functions as a Bayesian mixture model with an implemented efficient Gibbs sampler.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrence behaviors at a nanosecond scale, promising advancements in spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. In this context, two physical RC systems have been proposed and modeled: one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) for image classification, and another using 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs) for predicting nonlinear dynamic systems. Our micromagnetic simulations show that the nonlinear responses of MSMs and STNOs, triggered by current pulse stimulation, demonstrate that an RC system incorporating a single MSM excels in recognizing handwritten digits for image classification tasks. Additionally, complex and unknown nonlinear dynamic problems are effectively addressed by a physical RC system comprising 24 STNOs, as evidenced by its performance in second-order nonlinear dynamic system predictions and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms are fundamental to online platforms, from search engines to recommendation systems. In this study, we uncover an unexpected outcome of popularity-based rankings: items reporting a rare signal tend to capture a disproportionately large share of overall traffic. This "few-get-richer" phenomenon becomes apparent in environments with limited distinct categories of items (such as left-leaning versus right-leaning news sources), where rankings are determined by popularity. We provide a theoretical demonstration that this effect arises when users click predominantly on top-ranked items and exhibit diverse preferences toward different item categories. Through simulations, we examine how varying assumptions about the environment and user behavior impact the intensity of this effect. We further verify our predictions in an online experiment with real participants. Our results hold significant implications for understanding how misinformation spreads.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as an effective and straightforward technique for removing redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), leading to performance acceleration across various platforms. However, many pruning methods involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, often resulting in decreased inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration. To address these issues, we introduce a novel dimension of sparsity, known as pattern-based sparsity, which includes both pattern and connectivity sparsity, enhancing both accuracy and hardware compatibility. By designing meticulous patterns, our proposed pruning method consistently achieves improved accuracy and enhanced feature extraction capabilities across different DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our pattern-aware pruning framework supports simultaneous execution of pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. This new approach to pattern-based sparsity integrates naturally with compiler optimization, enabling highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis can be susceptible to bias when the control group differs significantly from the treated group, particularly due to historical events that impact the groups differently. Reducing this bias can be achieved by constructing a control group that more closely matches the treated group, selecting a subset of the overall control group for comparison. This approach is explored through simulation studies. We specifically examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences methodology, leveraging the increase in MRM activity following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. In our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we created a more closely matched control group and discovered a 95% confidence interval that includes the possibility of significant adverse effects, no effect, or minor beneficial effects.

When developing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to assess their ability to replicate the original data. This assessment can be effectively carried out using visual predictive checks (VPC). The process involves: (1) generating multiple simulations of the original study using the model in question, (2) calculating key estimates for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of these estimates with those from the original study. This method is generally easy to apply and is versatile. In this context, we focus on applying this technique to time-to-event data, particularly addressing situations where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event occurs.

The exploration of innovative concepts, perspectives, and challenges in the measurement and control of open quantum systems through sequential methods is presented. We delve into similar protocols that leverage repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, enabling us to: (i) restrict and safeguard quantum dynamics from decoherence, in line with Zeno physics principles; (ii) accurately forecast the likelihood of a quantum system transitioning into a desired quantum state through stochastic sequential measurements; (iii) effectively reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise by orthogonalizing the filter functions in the frequency domain, which govern the operation of the quantum sensor. Accomplishing these objectives will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, contributing to progress in quantum science and technology.

I can't think of anyone who has just one interest in life that occupies them entirely. In today's workforce, about 15 percent of American workers do not hold traditional full-time positions. These individuals are often half-time, part-time, contract workers, or temporary staff. The phrase "side hustle" captures the spirit of this approach, where people combine multiple activities to earn a living. The term originated in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, "hustle" referred to a kind of scam; by the 1950s, the term "side hustle" was used to denote legitimate work as well. A side hustle differs from a second job, which is typically pursued out of necessity.

Two identical domes represent two strikingly different design philosophies. One is constructed from thousands of steel components, while the other emerges from a single silk thread. One stands as a synthetic creation, and the other thrives organically. One imposes itself on its surroundings, whereas the other shapes its own environment. One is meticulously designed for nature, while the other is crafted by nature itself. Michelangelo famously observed that, within raw marble, he saw a figure striving to emerge. His chisel was his sole tool. In contrast, living organisms aren't sculpted; they grow and develop. Within each of our cells lies all the information necessary for every other cell's functioning and reproduction. It's important to remember that tools have profound impacts. Since the industrial revolution, design has been largely governed by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello, my name is Simone. You've probably heard the advice to imagine the audience naked to calm your nerves when speaking onstage. However, in 2018, this tactic feels a bit inappropriate and outdated. We're striving to move beyond such ideas, so we need a fresh approach to managing stage fright. I realized I would prefer a scenario where I could observe you just as much as you watch me—creating a sense of balance. If I had more eyes, it would make things more comfortable for all of us, don't you think?

To do two things at once is to do neither." This saying, often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, serves as a powerful criticism of multitasking. However, as with many historical quotes, it's possible that he never actually said it. What intrigues me, though, is whether this idea holds true. It's undoubtedly valid when considering actions like emailing during dinner, texting while driving, or perhaps live-tweeting a TED Talk. However, I would argue that for certain crucial activities, engaging in multiple tasks—two, three, or even four at a time—is exactly what we should be striving for. Take, for instance, Albert Einstein. In 1905, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

I realize this might sound unusual, but I believe robots have the potential to inspire us to become better humans. I spent my childhood in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, a town closely tied to Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and during my formative years, he would teach me the intricacies of how things function. Together, we embarked on projects like building model rockets and slot cars. This is the go-kart we constructed as a team. That's me at the wheel, alongside my sister and my best friend from that time. One day, when I was around 10 years old, my father came home and, during dinner, revealed that our next venture would be to build... a robot.

Sustainability addresses the what, where, and how of what is harvested, but it's the who and why that truly matter to me. I'm interested in the people behind my meal choices and understanding the impact I have on them, as well as how they affect me. I want to know why they fish and how they depend on the ocean's resources for their livelihood. Grasping these factors allows us to transform our view of seafood from a mere commodity into a means to rejuvenate our ecosystem, and it gives us the chance to appreciate the seafood we are privileged to enjoy. What should we call this? I believe it's restorative seafood. While sustainability focuses on the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative embodies the ability to renew and advance.

The hungry orphan yearning for another bowl of gruel. The spinster wilting away in her worn wedding gown. The cold-hearted miser haunted by the ghost of Christmas past. More than a century after his death, these vivid characters from Charles Dickens' work still resonate. His writing was so impactful that it inspired its own adjective. But what exactly makes Dickens' writing so exceptional? His fiction is rich with suspense, filled with brooding settings, unexpected plot twists, and intriguing mysteries. These elements kept his readers eagerly awaiting the next installment. Originally, his stories were serialized, published a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals, and only later compiled into books.

Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and an unwavering vision are the hallmarks of the most successful individuals. These are the brave souls who refuse to consider failure an option. What may appear to us as an insurmountable sea is merely an alluring stage for our next speaker, someone destined to perform there. Let's delve into the inspiring tale of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who is making significant waves in the realm of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (applause) Bhakti Sharma: Picture this—in the blistering Rajasthan heat on a sweltering summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old girl is perched on a moped behind her mother, oblivious to their destination. Twenty minutes later, that same young child finds herself fully immersed in water.

I will discuss a groundbreaking technology being developed at Oxford that we believe will revolutionize the production of computer games and Hollywood films. This technology involves the simulation of humans, complete with a virtual body and a simulated nervous system that governs that body. But before delving further into this technology, let's briefly examine the current state of human characters in video games. Here is a clip from "Grand Theft Auto 3," a game we briefly touched on yesterday. As you can observe, it is a remarkably well-designed game and ranks among the most successful of all time.

Like many people worldwide, my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup held in France earlier this summer. We admired these incredible athletes, marveled at the stunning goals, and appreciated the thrilling and fair play in the matches. Simultaneously, off the field, these women were advocating for equal pay—and, in some countries, for any compensation at all—for their participation in the sport. Driven by our growing fascination, we aimed to watch the matches live and concluded that one of the Spanish-speaking networks in the US offered the best coverage. A few games into the tournament, a friend remarked, "Why does it seem like all the advertisements are for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

You stand accused of a crime you didn't commit, and proving your innocence seems impossible. Insisting on your innocence could likely lead to a guilty verdict and execution. However, if you falsely confess, apologize, and implicate others, you could secure your freedom. This was the grim dilemma faced by those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They became victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misguided religious zeal, and a justice system that valued repentance over truth. The village of Salem was established in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life in Salem was characterized by strictness and isolation, with frequent conflicts involving Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers.

Currently, there are hundreds of thousands of individuals on transplant waiting lists, anxiously hoping for vital organs such as kidneys, hearts, and livers that could be lifesaving. Sadly, the demand far outweighs the available supply of donor organs. Imagine if, instead of waiting, we could engineer new, customized organs from scratch. This is the concept behind bioprinting, a rapidly developing field within regenerative medicine. Although we have not yet mastered the printing of complex organs, we are capable of creating simpler structures like blood vessels and channels used for nutrient and waste exchange. Bioprinting is akin to 3D printing, a technique that builds three-dimensional objects layer by layer.

Good afternoon, I'm delighted to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I aim to discuss a powerful phenomenon that's making waves and transforming our world—something we call "people power." To begin, let me share an anecdote, or for those who appreciate Monty Python, a sketch reminiscent of their style. Imagine this: it's December 15, 2010. Someone proposes a wager to you: peek into a crystal ball and witness the future—perfectly accurate—and then share it with the world. Intrigued, you accept the challenge, despite the old adage about curiosity. An hour later, you find yourself in the studio of a national television station, featured on a prime talk show, recounting your tale.

Let's start in 1964. Bob Dylan, at just 23 years old, is at the height of his career. Hailed as the voice of his generation, he's producing iconic songs at an extraordinary pace. However, there's a small group of critics who accuse him of plagiarizing others' music. Fast forward to 2004, Brian Burton, known as Danger Mouse, merges The Beatles' "White Album" with Jay-Z's "The Black Album," creating "The Grey Album." This new work quickly becomes an online sensation, prompting The Beatles' record label to issue numerous cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Notably, "The Grey Album" is a remix.

That statement seems quite self-evident. I began with this notion about 12 years ago, initially focusing on developing countries. Yet, you're here, representing various parts of the world. If you visualize a map of your country, you'll likely notice that in every nation, there are specific areas labeled as places "where quality teachers won't go." Ironically, these are often the very areas where issues tend to arise. Thus, we face a paradox: skilled educators avoid the regions where they are most needed. In 1999, I embarked on an experiment in New Delhi to tackle this challenge with a straightforward approach.

Currently, the majority of refugees reside in cities instead of refugee camps, accounting for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. This urban dwelling highlights the urgent need for a paradigm shift and innovative thinking. Instead of investing in building walls, it would be more beneficial to fund programs that empower refugees to support themselves. (applause) Refugees are often forced to leave behind their possessions, but they retain their skills and knowledge. When given the opportunity, they can lead productive lives, aiding not only themselves but also contributing positively to their host countries' development. I was born in Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, as the fifth child in a family of 12.

I have two important questions for you. First, whose legacy do you honor? And second, what principles do you uphold? I always begin my poetry workshops by asking students these questions because poetry can sometimes appear like an antiquated art form associated with old white men, seemingly born into old age, reminiscent of Benjamin Button. I pose these questions to my students and then reveal my answers in the form of three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, who descended from freedom fighters that broke their chains and transformed the world. They inspire me. I repeat these words as a mantra before every poetry performance. In fact, just a moment ago, I was over there in the corner, reciting them and making faces.

(Takes a deep breath) So, there was a time when music wasn't my primary source of income. For about five years after graduating from a reputable liberal arts university, I had a rather unique day job. (Chuckles) I was a self-employed living statue known as the Eight-Foot Bride. I love sharing this part of my life because people are always curious about who these so-called street performers are beyond the act. (Laughs) So, here I am. I would paint myself white, stand on a box, and place a hat or can at my feet. When someone dropped in money, I would give them a flower and engage in some intense eye contact. If they declined the flower, I would respond with a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

On October 4, 1957, the world observed with a mix of amazement and apprehension as the Soviet Union successfully launched Sputnik, the first artificial satellite, into space. This small metallic orb, less than two feet in diameter, ignited a space race between the United States and the Soviet Union that endured for eighteen years and profoundly transformed our world. However, Sputnik was not the first human-made object to reach space—that distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, which Germany employed in missile attacks against Allied cities during the closing years of World War II. Although the V-2 wasn't particularly effective, by the war's end, both the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. had seized the technology and the engineers behind it, utilizing them for their own burgeoning aerospace projects.

I am a cultural enthusiast, whose daily commute is powered by my trusty iPod—a device brimming with a diverse range of sounds, from Wagner and Mozart to pop sensation Christina Aguilera, country artist Josh Turner, and even gangsta rap by Kirk Franklin, alongside concertos, symphonies, and much more. I am an avid reader, exploring works from Ian McEwan to Stephanie Meyer, having thoroughly delved into the Twilight series. My passion also extends to my home theater, where I immerse myself in DVDs, video on demand, and a multitude of TV shows. My entertainment lineup includes "Law & Order: SVU," Tina Fey’s "30 Rock," and "Judge Judy," where "the people are real, the cases are real, and the rulings are final.

[Citizens of the World] [We are confronting a global crisis of unprecedented magnitude.] [Please prepare for a message from ... ] [the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres] The climate emergency is the defining challenge of our era. We are racing against time, and we are currently falling behind. There is a growing wave of impatience, particularly among young people, due to the lack of global action. We need heightened ambition from everyone: governments, municipalities, businesses, investors, and individuals worldwide. That’s why I am delighted that you are launching TED Countdown. Your influence and ideas can help hasten the move toward a carbon-neutral world by 2050. This is the only way to prevent the most severe effects of global warming. We possess the tools, the science, and the resources. Let us engage in this race with determination and vigor.

Menstruation—a simple term for a natural biological process—has been burdened by stigma for centuries, turning it into a topic we often discuss only in hushed tones. But why is this the case? At this very moment, over 800 million women across the globe are experiencing their period. It's a fundamental part of human existence, yet it remains an "embarrassing" topic to discuss openly. From both my own experience and those of the women around me, I can attest to how tiring it is. It's exhausting to discreetly retrieve a pad hidden in a brown paper bag, slipping it into your pocket during class, and rushing to the restroom as inconspicuously as possible. It's equally draining to endure lessons and meetings, outwardly appearing fine while internally battling intense period cramps.

The world's largest and most impactful environmental and industrial undertaking is located in the heart of Canada's boreal forest, the most extensive and pristine forest on the planet. This vast forest extends across northern Canada, including Labrador, where the George River Caribou Herd resides—the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world, with approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, during my visit, I was unable to spot any caribou, though the antlers bear testament to their presence. Throughout the boreal region, we are fortunate to have an incredible abundance of wetlands. Globally, wetlands are among the most threatened ecosystems, yet they are vital for cleaning air and water, sequestering significant amounts of greenhouse gases, and providing a home to a wide array of species.

Before the age of humans dawned, there existed the realm of the gods, a landscape of fields, plains, and gardens. Within this divine domain, four brothers roamed, bound to one another as their sole family, with the mystery of their parentage unknown. Among them, Deminan stood out; his skin bore painful scabs, and he was perplexed as to why he alone suffered this unusual misfortune. One day, while the supreme spirit, Yaya, tended to his gardens, Deminan and his brothers furtively entered Yaya’s home. After indulging in a feast and exploring, they noticed a massive gourd hanging in a corner. In their curiosity, as they attempted to peer into it, the gourd slipped from their grasp.

Seven years ago, I graduated from Berkeley with dual degrees in Molecular and Cell Biology and Linguistics. During a campus career fair, I secured an interview with a start-up known as Theranos. At that time, detailed information about the company was scarce, but what little was available appeared quite impressive. The company was working on developing a medical device capable of conducting a full blood panel using just a finger-stick sample, eliminating the need for a large needle in the arm. This innovation was intriguing not only because it reduced discomfort but also because it held the potential to revolutionize predictive diagnostics.

My path to becoming a polar specialist, focusing on photographing and studying the polar regions, began when I was just four years old. This journey started when my family relocated from southern Canada to the northern end of Baffin Island, near Greenland. We settled in a small Inuit community consisting of only 200 people, where ours was one of just three non-Inuit families. In this remote village, we lived without the conveniences of television, computers, or even a radio. We didn't have a telephone either. I spent all my time outdoors with the Inuit, learning and playing. The snow and ice became my playground, and the Inuit were my mentors. This unique experience sparked my lifelong fascination with the polar world.

We are often perceived as the organization that bears the brunt of unsuccessful social policies. I have no control over who comes to us or how long they remain. We receive individuals for whom every other support system has failed, those who have slipped through all existing social safety nets. These systems can't manage them, so it falls to us. Our role is to contain and control them. Over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very proficient at this, but it is not something to take pride in. Today, we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. Disturbingly, there are more Black men in prison today than were enslaved in 1850.

Let me take you on the thrilling journey of the Rosetta spacecraft, a mission that has captivated my passion over the past two years. The objective: to escort and successfully land a probe on a comet. To appreciate the significance of this quest, it's crucial to delve into the origins of our solar system. Around four and a half billion years ago, a cloud of gas and dust existed. At the heart of this cloud, our Sun was born and ignited. Simultaneously, what we now recognize as planets, comets, and asteroids also began to form. The prevailing theory suggests that as Earth cooled after its initial formation, it was heavily bombarded by comets. These impacts likely delivered not only water but also complex organic materials to our planet, potentially sparking the emergence of life.

Chris Anderson: Hello, TED community. Welcome back for another live conversation. Today’s discussion is as significant as they come. When we launched the "Build Back Better" series, our intention was to explore solutions for the challenges emerging from the pandemic and to envision ways to rebuild. However, the recent tragic death of George Floyd and the ensuing daily protests have underscored a new urgency that we must address. The question is: Can we rebuild better from this? Before we can even begin to answer, we need to comprehend the magnitude of this moment. 

Whitney Pennington Rodgers: Absolutely, Chris.

In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping excursion in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt spent his nights amidst the majestic sequoia trees, camped through a snowstorm, and engaged in lengthy discussions by the campfire with his host and guide, the renowned conservationist John Muir.
